proptary.title: NOTICE
proptary.para: The entire contents of this book are the exclusive property of United Parcel Service and are strictly confidential. Any unauthorized reproduction, use or disclosure of all or any part of its contents in any manner whatsoever will be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law.

cpyrght.holder: DISTRIBUTION TO AND USE OF THIS BOOK IS LIMITED EXCLUSIVELY TO THOSE ORGANIZATIONS AND INDIVIDUALS AUTHORIZED BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE.

This is a printed version of a controlled electronic document which is FAA approved. The electronic version is the source document for accuracy and effectivity, and is current through Revision 9 of the master electronic document, effective xx/xx/xx.

geninfo.title: ALL MANUAL HOLDERS
geninfo.para: This document has been carefully prepared and is as error free as is practical. However, we expect some errors may exist, and we invite your comments and recommendations for correction.

To request correction of misspellings and other non-technical errors, please contact Flight Publications at (502) 359-8551/8561 or stop by our office at 802 Grade Lane in Louisville, Kentucky. Corrections will be made at the next scheduled manual revision.

To request technical changes, reference the Flight Operations Web Site for the official MEL Change Request Form. Requests will be reviewed and, if approved, included in the next and/or future MEL revision.
We appreciate your interest in the quality improvement of our manuals.

para.emphasis: RETAIN THIS RECORD IN THE FRONT OF THE MANUAL. ON RECEIPT OF REVISIONS, INSERT REVISED PAGES IN THE MANUAL AND ENTER DATE INSERTED AND INITIALS.

entry.para: EACH MANUAL HOLDER ISSUED AN AIR CARRIER MANUAL IS RESPONSIBLE FOR KEEPING IT UP TO DATE WITH CHANGES AND ADDITIONS FURNISHED. (FAR 121.137)
REVIEW THIS REVISION AND FILE IN YOUR MANUAL IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS:

para.emphasis: NOTE:THIS MANUAL IS PROVIDED IN ITS ENTIRETY.

entry.para: SEE HIGHLIGHTS OF CHANGES FOR ITEMS AFFECTED BY NEW REVISION.

textset.chgdesc: Revises FUEL SPAR VLV message and deletes FUEL SPAR VLV Advisory message.
textset.title: EICAS MESSAGES
textset.para: The Engine Indication and Crew Alerting System (EICAS) provides displays of engine parameters, crew alerts of non-normal conditions, systems status and maintenance data. EICAS messages are divided into the following categories:

entry.para: Red message and light, Master Warning light illuminates, Master Warning Aural sounds, immediate crew action required.
Amber message and light, Master Caution light illuminates, Master Caution Aural sounds, immediate crew awareness and future crew action required.
Amber message and light, crew awareness and possible future crew action required.
A reminder of normal operational or system condition displayed in white text for routine crew awareness only.

White message appears on EICAS Status page to indicate a system condition which affects airplane dispatch. Status messages are checked prior to engine start and condition should be corrected or dispatched per the MEL. There are no inflight crew procedures associated with Status messages.
A caret symbol shows in front of a message when there is no procedure in the quick reference handbook (QRH).

textset.para: Any monitored faults that affect airplane dispatch status will be displayed on EICAS as a Status or Alert level (Warning, Caution, or Advisory) message, with a corresponding correlated maintenance message. System faults displayed at Status level or Alert level should be resolved by maintenance action or MEL relief prior to engine start. After engine start, EICAS Alert messages are the primary means of alerting the crew to non-normal conditions or improper configuration.
Maintenance messages do not prohibit dispatch but must be corrected in accordance with United Parcel Service’s approved maintenance program

The EICAS Message List which follows contains those messages which are in the Warning, Caution, Advisory or Status categories. This section is provided as a "Quick Reference" between EICAS messages and Minimum Equipment List (MEL) items which may provide dispatch relief

Normal crew procedures require checking status messages during cockpit preparation to determine airplane dispatchability. CAUTION and ADVISORY messages do not require crew action up to this time because they reflect systems not yet configured for flight and should disappear as a result of crew action during flight deck preparation. WARNING messages should be dealt with immediately whenever they are displayed.

Any message adversely affecting safe continuation of the flight or requiring crew attention, will appear as an EICAS alert message (WARNING, CAUTION or ADVISORY). From engine start until shutdown at the completion of flight, EICAS alert messages are the primary means of alerting the flight crews to non-normal conditions or improper configuration. After engine start and prior to takeoff, any alert message requires accomplishment of the appropriate non-normal procedure by the crew. Upon completion of the non-normal procedure and prior to takeoff, consult the MEL to determine if relief is available. Status messages observed prior to takeoff may require crew action. Attempt to clear status message, if unable, refer to the MEL to determine appropriate action. There are no safety issues or QRH procedures associated with an in-flight status message. Do not use the MEL in-flight. Make a logbook entry upon arrival at the scheduled destination.

Dispatch capability with an invalid EICAS message depends on the message level. Dispatch with invalid status level messages is allowed by MEL item 31-61-4, provided that either the associated equipment is verified to operate normally or the dispatch deviations for the associated equipment are observed. However, there is no specific item in the MEL for dispatch with invalid Alert level (Warning, Caution, or Advisory) messages, since they are required for in-flight crew awareness or action as described at the beginning of Section 1. Thus, if an Alert message is displayed, dispatch is allowed only if there is MEL relief for the associated equipment fault or failure, and the applicable dispatch deviations are applied. If system deactivation procedures result in an associated Alert message remaining OFF, dispatch may be acceptable if no in-flight alert is needed for the deactivated equipment. In most cases, appropriate placards or flight log entries provide sufficient crew awareness.

The MEL lists the items of airplane equipment that may be inoperative, and the conditions under which dispatch is allowed. The purpose of the Cross-Reference List is to relate an EICAS message indicating an equipment fault or failure to the MEL item(s) that allows dispatch with the condition indicated by the message. It is intended to assist operators in quickly identifying the proper MEL items to consult to determine airplane dispatchability. The list includes the message, a description of the condition(s) that result in message display, message level, and possible MEL cross reference as follows:

entry.para: The indicated MEL item should be consulted for possible dispatch when the associated message is displayed. If the message description indicates more than one possible equipment fault, multiple MEL items may be listed. In such cases, additional system troubleshooting may be required to determine the equipment fault(s) that are present.
Takeoff is not allowed unless the message is invalid. In such cases, MEL item 31-61-4 may be used to dispatch.
The message does not necessarily indicate a system fault or failure. Dispatch is allowed provided appropriate crew procedures are followed.
The ACARS system needs flight crew attention or action.
An uplinked message has been received with a voice contact request.

An uplinked message has been received; an uplinked message has been received with a voice contact request; ACARS system needs flight crew attention or action; ACARS has no VHF, SATCOM, or ATC RF link available.
ACARS Management Unit (MU) failure or no activity.
ACARS has no VHF, SATCOM, or ATC RF link available.
ACARS is setting the VHF transceiver to voice mode.
The party on the ground with whom the flight crew desires voice communications cannot be reached because ground circuits are busy or his telephone is already in use.
Aft cargo zone _ loop A fire or fault.
Aft cargo zone _ loop B fire or fault.
Primary and alternate air/ground logic disagree - wing and/or body gear tilt. Inhibited by battery bus off or AC bus 2 off.
Either or both aileron lockout actuator unlocked when it should be locked, or locked when it should be unlocked, or failed.
Either or both aileron lockout actuator unlocked when it should be locked, or locked when it should be unlocked, or failed.
Airspeed in the low speed amber band.
Failure of the altitude alert system or loss of input to the integrated display system.

Output power from either primary or alternate AIR-GND power supplies in the PSEU has been lost, causing the respective air ground logic to fail. If in RTO or landing, the thrust reversers, auto speedbrake, autobrakes and ground spoiler will be inop. Engine idle will be high idle.
Failure of the altitude alert system or loss of input to the integrated display system.
Loss of automatic altitude callout function.
Loss of automatic altitude callout function.
Uncorrected baro altitude disagrees by more than 200 feet for more than 5 seconds. Inhibited below 400 feet radio altitude.
Excessive deviation from selected altitude by 300 feet or more.
Any nacelle or wing anti-ice system selected on and TAT > 12 degrees C and ice detector does not detect ice.
Any nacelle anti-ice system selected on and TAT > 12 degrees C and ice detector does not detect ice.
Engine _ anti-ice valve disagrees with command with engine running, or NAI valve pressure regulator failed (PW only), or TAI regulator valve failed (GE only).

Any wing anti-ice system selected on and TAT > 12 degrees C and ice detector does not detect ice.

Fault in antiskid system (normal or alternate). Inhibited by ANTISKID OFF status message.
Antiskid power off on all 16 wheels or parking brake valve not fully open with parking brake released or loss of both bus inputs from BSCU.
Antiskid power off on all 16 wheels or parking brake valve not fully open with parking brake released or loss of both bus inputs from BSCU.
Right angle of attack (AOA) sensor failure reported by the Center Air Data Computer (ADC) on the ground.
Right angle of attack (AOA) sensor failure reported by the Center Air Data Computer (ADC).
Autopilot reversionary configuration. No autopilot redundancy.
APU automatic fault shutdown while switch is in on position, or switch in stop position and no fault indication with rpm greater than 95%. (APU auto event)
APU automatic fault shutdown while switch is in on position, or switch in stop position and no fault indication with rpm greater than 95%. (APU auto event)
APU fire loop A fire or fault.
APU fire loop B fire or fault.
APU fuel valve disagree with commanded position or APU fuel pump low pressure when commanded on.
APU fuel pump low pressure when APU commanded on.
APU fuel valve disagree with commanded position.
APU is running and Aux Gen Ctrl relay (AGCR) 1 is open.
APU is running and Aux Gen Ctrl relay (AGCR) 1 is open.

Loss of all engaged autopilots (auto or manual event).

Aux refuel valve 2 failed open and refuel panel door is closed.

textset.title: PREAMBLE
textset.para: The following is applicable for authorized certificate holders operating under Federal Aviation Regulations (FAR) Parts 121, 125, 129, 135: The FAR require that all equipment installed on an aircraft in compliance with the Airworthiness Standards and the Operating Rules must be operative. However, the Rules also permit the publication of a Minimum Equipment List (MEL) where compliance with certain equipment requirements is not necessary in the interests of safety under all operating conditions. Experience has shown that with the various levels of redundancy designed into aircraft, operation of every system or installed component may not be necessary when the remaining operative equipment can provide an acceptable level of safety. A Master Minimum Equipment List (MMEL) is developed by the FAA, with participation by the aviation industry, to improve aircraft utilization and thereby provide more convenient and economic air transportation for the public. The FAA approved MMEL includes those items of equipment related to airworthiness and operating regulations and other items of equipment which the Administrator finds may be inoperative and yet maintain an acceptable level of safety by appropriate conditions and limitations; it does not contain obviously required items such as wings, flaps, and rudders. The MMEL is the basis for development of individual operator MELs which take into consideration the operator’s particular aircraft equipment configuration and operational conditions. Operator MELs, for administrative control, may include items not contained in the MMEL; however, relief for administrative control items must be approved by the Administrator. An operator’s MEL may differ in format from the MMEL, but cannot be less restrictive than the MMEL. The individual operator’s MEL, when approved and authorized, permits operation of the aircraft with inoperative equipment.

Equipment not required by the operation being conducted and equipment in excess of FAR requirements are included in the MEL with appropriate conditions and limitations. The MEL must not deviate from the Aircraft Flight Manual Limitations, Emergency Procedures or with Airworthiness Directives. It is important to remember that all equipment related to the airworthiness and the operating regulations of the aircraft not listed on the MMEL must be operative.

Suitable conditions and limitations in the form of placards, maintenance procedures, crew operating procedures and other restrictions as necessary are specified in the MEL to ensure that an acceptable level of safety is maintained.

The MEL is intended to permit operation with inoperative items of equipment for a period of time until repairs can be accomplished. It is important that repairs be accomplished at the earliest opportunity. In order to maintain an acceptable level of safety and reliability, the MMEL establishes limitations on the duration of and conditions for operation with inoperative equipment. The MEL provides for release of the aircraft for flight with inoperative equipment. When an item of equipment is discovered to be inoperative, it is reported by making an entry in the Aircraft Maintenance Record/Logbook as prescribed by FAR. The item is then either repaired or may be deferred per the MEL or other approved means acceptable to the Administrator prior to further operation. MEL conditions and limitations do not relieve the operator from determining that the aircraft is in condition for safe operation with items of equipment inoperative.

When these requirements are met, an Airworthiness Release, Aircraft Maintenance Record/Logbook entry, or other approved documentation is issued as prescribed by FAR. Such documentation is required prior to operation with any item of equipment inoperative.

Operators are responsible for exercising the necessary operational control to ensure that an acceptable level of safety is maintained. When operating with multiple inoperative items, the interrelationships between those items and the effect on aircraft operation and crew workload will be considered.
Operators are to establish a controlled and sound repair program including the parts, personnel, facilities, procedures, and schedules to ensure timely repair.
WHEN USING THE MEL, COMPLIANCE WITH THE STATED INTENT OF THE PREAMBLE, DEFINITIONS, AND THE CONDITIONS AND LIMITATIONS SPECIFIED IN THE MEL IS REQUIRED.

numlitem.para: System Definitions.
System numbers are based on the Air Transport Association (ATA) Specification and items are numbered sequentially.

"Item" means the equipment, system, component, or function listed after the MEL number. Repair interval categories (A, B, C, and D) are listed in the Repair Int Category block. Repair intervals are described in definition 22.

"Number Installed" (Installed block) is the number (quantity) of items normally installed in the aircraft. This number represents the aircraft configuration considered in developing this MEL. Should the number be a variable (e.g., passenger cabin items) a number is not required.
"Number Required for Dispatch" (Required block) is the minimum number (quantity) of items required for operation provide the conditions specified in Remarks and Exceptions are met.

note.para: Where the MMEL shows a variable number required for dispatch, the MEL must reflect the actual number required for dispatch or an alternate means of configuration control approved by the Administrator.

numlitem.para: "Remarks or Exceptions" (in the Remarks and Exceptions section) includes a statement either prohibiting or permitting operation with a specific number of items inoperative, provisos (conditions and limitations) for such operation, and appropriate notes.

References given in the Remarks and Exceptions section are to bring attention to certain interrelationships between the subject item and other MEL items or DMP and/or AOM material. These references are intended to assist with compliance, but do not relieve the operator of the responsibility for determining such interrelationships as stated in the Preamble.

A Vertical bar (change bar) in the margin indicates a change or addition in the adjacent text for the current revision of that item only. Deletions will not be annotated by change bars, but will be delineated in the Highlights of Changes page(s). The change bar is dropped at the next revision of that item.

"Airplane Flight Manual" (AFM) is the document required for type certification and approved by the responsible FAA Aircraft Certification Office. The FAA approved AFM for the specific aircraft is listed on the applicable Type Certificate Data Sheet.

"As required by FAR" means that the listed item is subject to certain provisions (restrictive or permissive) expressed in the Federal Aviation Regulations operating rules. The number of items required by the FAR must be operative. When the listed item is not required by FAR it may be inoperative for time specified by repair category. The term "14 CFR" may be substituted for "FAR" in MMELs or operator MELs.
Each inoperative item must be placarded to inform and remind the crewmembers and maintenance personnel of the equipment condition.

note.para: To the extent practical, placards should be located adjacent to the control or indicator for the item affected; however, unless otherwise specified, placard wording and location will be determined by the operator.

numlitem.para: "—" Symbol (in the Installed block) indicates a variable number (quantity) of the item installed.

note.para: Where the MMEL shows a variable number installed, the MEL must reflect the actual number installed or an alternate means of configuration control approved by the Administrator.

numlitem.para: "Deleted" after a sequence number indicates the item was previously listed but is now required to be operative if installed in the aircraft.
"ER" refers to Extended Operations (ETOPS) of an airplane with operational approval to conduct ETOPS in accordance with the applicable regulations.
"Federal Aviation Regulations" (FAR) means the applicable portions of the Federal Aviation Act and Federal Aviation Regulations.
"Flight Day" means a 24 hour period (from midnight to midnight) SDF local time, as established by UPS, during which at least one flight is initiated for the affected aircraft.
"Icing Conditions" means an atmospheric environment that may cause ice to form on the aircraft (structural) or in the engine(s) (induction).
Alphabetical symbol (in the Remarks and Exceptions section) indicates a provision (condition or limitation) that must be complied with for operation with the listed item inoperative.

"Inoperative" means a system and/or component malfunction to the extent that it does not accomplish its intended purpose and/or is not consistently functioning normally within its approved operating limit(s) or tolerance(s). If an item of equipment is deferred or any proviso indicates an item of equipment is inoperative or considered to be inoperative, that equipment shall not be used during flight unless authorized by the MEL.

"Notes:" – In the Remarks and Exception section provide additional information for crewmember or maintenance consideration. Notes are used to identify applicable material which are intended to assist with compliance, but do not relieve the operator of the responsibility for compliance with all applicable requirements. Notes are not a part of the provisos.

Inoperative components of an inoperative system: Inoperative items which are components of a system which is inoperative are usually considered components directly associated with and having no other function than to support that system. (Warning/caution systems associated with the inoperative system must be operative unless relief is specifically authorized per the MMEL).

"(M)" symbol in the Remarks and Exceptions section indicates a requirement for a specific maintenance procedure which must be accomplished prior to operation with the listed item inoperative. Normally these procedures are accomplished by maintenance personnel; however, other personnel may be qualified and authorized to perform certain functions. Procedures requiring specialized knowledge or skill, or requiring the use of tools or test equipment should be accomplished by maintenance personnel. The satisfactory accomplishment of all maintenance procedures, regardless of who performs them, is the responsibility of the operator. Appropriate procedures, including the identification of qualified personnel authorized to accomplish them are required to be published as part of the Operator's Manual or MEL.

"(O)" symbol in the Remarks and Exceptions section indicates a requirement for a specific operations procedure which must be accomplished in planning for and/or operating with the listed item inoperative. Normally these procedures are accomplished by the flight crew; however, other personnel may be qualified and authorized to perform certain functions. The satisfactory accomplishment of all procedures, regardless of who performs them, is the responsibility of the operator. Appropriate procedures, including the identification of qualified personnel authorized to accomplish them, are required to be published as part of the Operator's Manual or MEL.

note.para: The (M) and (O) symbols are required in the operator's MEL unless otherwise authorized by the Administrator.

numlitem.para: "Deactivated" and "Secured" means that the specified component must be put into an acceptable condition for safe flight. An acceptable method of securing or deactivating will be listed in the Operations Procedure section, Maintenance Procedure section, or corresponding Dispatch Maintenance Procedure.
"Visual Flight Rules" (VFR) is as defined in FAR Part 91. This precludes a pilot from filing an Instrument Flight Rules (IFR) flight plan.

"Visual Meteorological Conditions" (VMC) means the atmospheric environment is such that would allow a flight to proceed under the visual flight rules applicable to the flight. This does not preclude operating under Instrument Flight Rules.
"Visible Moisture" means an atmospheric environment containing water in any form that can be seen in natural or artificial light, for example, clouds, fog, rain, sleet, hail, or snow.

"Passenger Convenience Items" means those items related to passenger convenience, comfort or entertainment such as, but not limited to, galley equipment, movie equipment, ash trays, stereo equipment, overhead reading lamps, etc.

Repair Intervals: (Repair Int Category block) All users of an MEL approved under FAR 121, 125, 129 and 135 must effect repairs of inoperative systems or components, deferred in accordance with the MEL, at or prior to the repair times established by the following letter designators:

note.para: It is permissible to dispatch an aircraft provided the time limitation has not expired at the time of blockout.

numlitem.para: Category A. Items in this category shall be repaired within the time interval specified in the remarks section of the operator's approved MEL. For time intervals specified in "calendar days" or "flight days," the day the malfunction was recorded in the aircraft maintenance record/logbook is excluded. For all other time intervals (flights, flight legs,cycles, hours, etc), repair tracking begins at the point when the malfunction is deferred in accordance with the operator's approved MEL.

Category B. Items in this category shall be repaired within three (3) consecutive calendar days (72 hours), excluding the day the malfunction was recorded in the aircraft maintenance record/logbook. For example, if it were recorded at 10 a.m. on January 26th, the three day interval would begin at midnight the 26th and end at midnight the 29th. All time will be based on SDF local time.

Category C. Items in this category shall be repaired within ten (10) consecutive calendar days (240 hours), excluding the day the malfunction was recorded in the aircraft maintenance record/logbook. For example, if it were recorded at 10 am. on January 26th, the 10 day interval would begin at midnight the 26th and end at midnight February 5th. All time will be based on SDF local time.

Category D. Items in this category shall be repaired within one hundred and twenty (120) consecutive calendar days (2880 hours), excluding the day the malfunction was recorded in the aircraft maintenance log and/or record.

An operator who has the authorization to use an MEL also has the authority to approve extensions to the maximum repair interval for category B and C items provided the responsible Flight Standards District Office (FSDO) is notified within 24 hours of the MEL extension. The operator is not authorized to extend A and D items in the MEL. Misuse of the MEL extension authority may result in the operators OpSpecs/Mspecs being amended by removing the authority for the operator to use the MEL extension authority and/or use an MEL.

Boeing aircraft equipped with Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting Systems (EICAS), provide different priority levels of system messages (WARNING, CAUTION, ADVISORY, STATUS and MAINTENANCE). Any messages that affects aircraft dispatch status will be displayed at a STATUS message level or higher. The absence of an EICAS STATUS or higher level (WARNING, CAUTION, ADVISORY) indicates that the system/component is operating within its approved operating limits or tolerances.

System conditions that result only in a maintenance level message, i.e. no correlation with a higher level EICAS message, do not affect dispatch and do not require action other than as addressed within an operators standard maintenance program.

"Administrative control item" means an item listed by the operator in the MEL for tracking and informational purposes. It may be added to an operator's MEL by approval of the Principal Operations Inspector provided no relief is granted, or provided conditions and limitations are contained in an approved document (i.e., Structural Repair Manual, airworthiness directive, etc.). If relief other than that granted by an approved document is sought for an administrative control item, a request must be submitted to the Administrator. If the request results in review and approval by the FOEB, the item becomes an MMEL item rather than an administrative control item.
Not applicable.
"Excess items" means those items that have been installed that are redundant to the requirements of the FARs.

"Day of Discovery" is the calendar day an equipment/instrument malfunction was recorded in the aircraft maintenance log and or record. This day is excluded from the calendar days or flight days specified in the MEL for the repair of an inoperative item of equipment. This provision is applicable to all MEL items, i.e., categories "A, B, C, and D."

"Considered Inoperative", as used in the provisos means that item must be treated for dispatch, taxi and flight purposes as though it were inoperative. The item shall not be used or operated until the original deferred item is repaired. Additional actions include: documenting the item on the dispatch release (if applicable), placarding, and complying with all remarks, exceptions, and related MMEL provisions, including any (M) and (O) procedures and observing the repair category.

"Is not used" in the provisos, remarks or exceptions for an MMEL item may specify that another item relieved in the MMEL "is not used." In such cases, crewmembers should not activate, actuate, or otherwise utilize that component or system under normal operations. It is not necessary for the operators to accomplish the (M) procedures associated with the item. However, operational requirements must be complied with, and an additional placard must be affixed, to the extent practical, adjacent to the control or indicator for the item that is not used to inform crewmembers that a component or system is not to be used under normal operations.

Nonessential equipment and furnishings (NEF) are those items installed on the aircraft as part of the original certification, supplemental type certificate, or engineering order that have no effect on the safe operation of flight and would not be required by the applicable certification rules or operational rules. They are those items that if inoperative, damaged or missing have no effect on the aircraft's ability to be operated safely under all operational conditions. These nonessential items may be installed in areas including, but not limited to, the passenger compartment, flight deck area, service areas, cargo areas, crew rest areas, lavatories, and galley areas. NEF items are not items already identified in the MEL or CDL of the applicable aircraft. They do not include items that are functionally required to meet the certification rule or for compliance with any operational rule. Operator's NEF process shall not provide for deferral of items within serviceable limits identified in the manufacture's maintenance manual or operator's approved maintenance program such as wear limits, fuel/hydraulic leak rates, oil consumption, etc. Cosmetic items that are fully serviceable but worn or soiled may be deferred under an operator's NEF process.
"Affected" – refers to the subject item of equipment (component, system or function) listed in the title section.
"Associated" – refers to a related component, system or function other than the subject one.
Class E Cargo – 747-400 UPS aircraft are in a Class E Cargo configuration for the Main Deck.
Class C Cargo – 747-400 UPS aircraft are in a Class C Cargo configuration for the Lower Deck.

Effectivity – Aircraft Registration Numbers listed in the Title section indicate the effectivity which applies to an MEL item number. These effectivities are as accurate and up-to-date as possible as of the publication revision date. However, if an aircraft registration number does not appear in the Title section, but physical inspection of the aircraft indicates an item is installed, relief may be taken and the item deferred provided the number of items required for dispatch are operational and the appropriate procedures are accomplished.

note.para: Some items listed in the Minimum Equipment List reference a corresponding maintenance procedure in the Dispatch Maintenance Procedures section. It is the responsibility of maintenance personnel to ensure that applicable DMP procedures are accomplished.

numlitem.para: "Instrument Meteorological Conditions" (IMC) — Meteorological conditions expressed in terms of visibility distance from cloud, and ceiling less than the minimums specified for visual meteorological conditions.
"Not Applicable" – in the Title section refers to equipment or subcomponents of a system which are no longer installed or part of the configuration or UPS is not taking relief.
References in this document to the Aircraft Operations Manual (AOM) replace the references in the FAA Master Minimum Equipment List to Aircraft Flight Manual (AFM).
"Repair" – Means such maintenance action, including replacement, as necessary to restore an inoperative item to an operative condition.
"Sub-System" – A major functional portion of a system which contributes to operational completeness of the system.
"System" – A combination of interrelated items arranged to perform a specific function.
"Time In Service" – The time from the moment an aircraft leaves the surface of the earth until it touches it at the next point of landing (as defined in FAR Part l).

"Operations Procedure" – This section includes specific (O) operations procedures called for in the Remarks and Exceptions section, which must be accomplished in planning for and/or operating with the listed item inoperative. (Refer to the (O) definition, number 16 in this chapter.)

"Maintenance Procedure" When a (M) Maintenance Procedure is required, a reference will display ("Accomplish Dispatch Maintenance Procedure XX-XX-XX") in the Maintenance Procedure section of the MEL. This reference links the procedure to a specific DMP. However, when a (M) Maintenance Procedure is NOT required, the Maintenance Procedure section in the MEL may include Notes, Downgrade statements and CAT boxes.

"Limitations/Performance Penalties" – This section includes specific limitations or performance penalties that must be complied with during flight planning, prior to departure, en route or during approach and landing. Compliance with the limitations in this section do not relieve the user from complying with the Repair Int Category block, Required block, Remarks and Exceptions section, Operations Procedures section, and Maintenance Procedure section.
Reduced Vertical Separation Minimums (RVSM) – A program to permit operations of 1000 feet vertical separation.
"Blockout" – The time the aircraft begins movement for the purpose of takeoff either by pushback, tow or under its own power.

Required Navigation Performance Capability (RNP) is a statement of navigation performance necessary for operation within a defined airspace. RNP-10 is defined in FAA order 8400.12 series and European Basic Area Navigation (BRNAV/RNP-5) in Advisory Circular #90-96 series.

Required Navigation Performance Capability is a standard for continuing airworthiness based on a more stringent separation parameter to be implemented as part of a worldwide ICAO effort to implement the Future Air Navigation Systems (FANS), Communication/Navigation/Surveillance (CNS) and Air Traffic Management (ATM) concept. Currently, a 50 nautical mile lateral separation on the North Pacific (NOPAC) and selected Central Pacific (CEPAC) routes, when implemented, are based on RNP-10 criteria. This performance capability is similar to existing minimum navigation performance specifications (MNPS) over the North Atlantic. At least two Long Range Navigation systems must be operational at oceanic entry points. MNPS or RNP-5 navigation accuracy BRNAV requirements are met where RNP-10 is authorized.
Operative – The available functions meet the intended purpose required to complete the flight.

UPS Lettered Revision (Red Revision) — is an interim revision that is designated by a letter, with the intent of addressing Airworthiness Directives and/or safety of flight issues that impact the MEL/DMP. Additionally, an Engineering Order (EO) will be issued to supersede the affected MEL/DMP until the UPS Lettered Revision is published.

"Ballast Weights" – Ballast is any weight added to the aircraft for the purpose of CG control. It will be loaded on/in a ULD and loaded uniformly and with barrier nets in place. NOTE: Materials loaded on/in a ULD for use as ballast during flight, must not consist of any combustible, flammable or otherwise hazardous material. The weight of ballast materials, such as concrete blocks, metal plates, and sand bags must be distributed evenly across the floor of the ULD and secured to prevent shifting during flight.

textset.title: B747-400 CAT 2/3 SIGNIFICANT SYSTEMS/COMPONENTS

numlitem.para: Maintenance personnel shall perform maintenance on the maintenance significant and/or flight operations significant system(s) component(s) listed, per one of the following procedures, as applicable:
Qualified Maintenance Personnel Procedures
Non-Qualified Maintenance Personnel Procedures

textset.para: Components required for CAT 2/3 operations which may possess complex operational, aircraft system interface, and performance degradation characteristics unfamiliar to and/or undetectable by untrained maintenance personnel.

entry.para: RADIO ALTIMETERS ANTENNA AND COAX CABLE

textset.para: Component(s)/System(s) required for CAT 2/3 operations which do not possess complex operational, aircraft system interface, an performance degradation characteristics.

entry.para: WINDOW HEAT ON WINDOWS NO. 1 AND NO. 2

textset.para: In addition to the flight instruments and radio navigation equipment required by FAR Part 121, the following equipment is required to operate for the specified CAT 2/3 operation. Detailed description and operation information, associated with CAT 2/3, is specified in the AMM. Minimum system configuration for dispatch into lower weather minima is specified in the MEL.

graphic.title: B747-400 CATEGORY 2/3 NON-QUALIFIED MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL PROCEDURES LINE MAINTENANCE/NON-ROUTINE WRITE-UP

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard below Captain's PFD on P-1-1 panel "A/C OZONE CONVERTER ___ INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Flight Deck Vent Fan – With Draw Through Smoke Detection System

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard Flight Deck FAN switch "INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Flight Deck Vent Fan – Without Draw Through Smoke Detection System

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided Flight Deck Window Heater Systems (No. 1 and No. 2) are operative.

numlitem.para: Flight Deck Window Heater Systems No. 1 and No. 2 must be operative.

placard.para: Placard Flight Deck FAN switch "INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Forward Cargo Air Conditioning (A/C) Overboard Valves

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided one valve remains closed.

note.para: Forward Cargo A/C will be unavailable.
The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
CGO OVBD VLV FWD
FWD CAR OVBD VLV

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals, or perishables is prohibited in the forward cargo compartment.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel "FWD CARGO OVBD BKUP VLV(s) INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Manually close and verify that the cargo overboard valve or the cargo overboard backup valve remains closed by either method 1 or 2.
Method 1: If Power Available.
To verify this, check the EICAS MAINTENANCE PAGE as follows:
On the CDU select Menu, CMC, EICAS, MAINTENANCE PAGE.
Select <21 ECS.
>OTHER SYSTEMS
>SUPPLY
<DISPLAY
The lower EICAS will display both valves. The CGO OVERBOARD VALVE is closed when O.O. is displayed, the BACKUP VALVE will display CLOSED.
Method 2: Manual Check or Valve Not Closed.
Check the manual override lever on these valves in the fwd lower cargo compartment RH side, however pallet position "3" must be empty to access.
To ensure these valves remain closed, pull following CB's on panel P180 (located in the RH tunnel fwd of the E/E compartment).

entry.para: FWD CGO EXT BUP VLV PWR

item.title: Forward Cargo A/C Ground Exhaust Fans

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Install placard below Captain's PFD on P-1-1 panel "____ FWD CARGO A/C GND EXH FAN(s) INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Forward Cargo A/C Ground Exhaust Shutoff Valves

remarks.para: Two may be inoperative provided one left and one right valve is operative.

placard.para: Install placard below Captain's PFD on P-1-1 panel "____ FWD CARGO A/C GRD EXH S/O VLV – INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.para: Verify operation of the forward cargo ground exhaust valves by doing a forward cargo overboard valve system ground test on any CMC CDU.

numlitem.para: Position Overhead Maintenance panel (P461) or Forward Cargo Compartment (P86) CARGO COND AIR FLOW RATE selector OFF.
On CMC main menu choose GROUND TEST. Select chapter 21 AIR CONDITIONING - CARGO OVBD SYSTEM.
Check that IN PROGRESS is displayed on CMC CDU.
Press FAIL key on CMC to observe messages. Ensure that at least one left and one right valve is operative.

item.title: Forward Cargo A/C Overboard Check Valve

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided forward Cargo Air Conditioning is not used.

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals, or perishables is prohibited in the forward cargo compartment.

placard.para: Placard Cargo Cond Air Flow Rate selector "DO NOT OPERATE". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Position the LOWER LOBE CARGO COND AIR FLOW RATE selector to OFF, LOW AFT, or HIGH AFT as required.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Forward Overboard Valve is deactivated closed,
Operation is limited to two Air Conditioning Packs,
Procedures are established and used to verify the aft cargo compartment remains empty or contains only empty cargo handling equipment, ballast (ballast may be loaded in ULDs), or Fly Away Kits,

For Combi, procedures are established and used to verify main deck cargo compartment remains empty or contains only empty cargo handling equipment, ballast (ballast may be loaded in ULDs), or Fly Away Kits,
For Passenger/Combi, one Lavatory/Galley fan is verified to be operative,
Aft Cargo Heat remains OFF,
If installed, humidifiers are operated manually,
If installed, Fwd Cargo Heat (electrical) is deactivated, and
If installed, the main cabin exhaust valve(s) is deactivated closed.

note.para: UPS does not carry Fly Away Kits in voided cargo compartments.
UPS -400F's and BCF's do not have humidifiers or cabin exhaust valves.
The following EICAS message(s) may remain displayed:
ECS MISC CARD

numlitem.para: &Ensuretheloadsupervisor;
Operation limited to two packs.
Aft lower cargo compartment is empty, or contains only empty cargo handling equipment.

placard.para: Placard adjacent to Pack selector "ESC MISC CARD INOP - USE TWO PACKS MAX". Placard adjacent to AFT Cargo Heat Switch "DO NOT OPERATE - LEAVE AFT CARGO HT OFF". Install placard below Captain's PFD on P-1-1 panel "FORWARD CARGO COMP HEATING SYS INOP". Enter items in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Deactivate the forward overboard valve in the closed position. Valve is located on the inside of the fuselage to the left of the nose gear wheel well.
Open and collar the P6 panel FWD OVBD VLV CONT and the P180 panel FWD OVBD VALVE POWER circuit breakers.
Disconnect, cap, and stow electrical connector DV462 from valve.
Manually position the operating lever/position indicator to the closed position.
Lockwire lever to actuator mounting screws.
Deactivate forward cargo heat (electrical) per MEL 21-43-1.

item.chgdesc: Adds Note in Limitations.
item.title: ECS Misc Card – Non-ER Operations

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Forward Overboard Valve is deactivated open,
Extended overwater flight prohibited,
Operation is limited to two Air Conditioning Packs,

Procedures are established and used to verify the forward lower lobe cargo compartment remains empty or contains only empty cargo handling equipment, ballast (ballast may be loaded in ULDs), or Fly Away Kits,

For Freighter, procedures are established and used to verify main deck cargo compartment remains empty or contains only empty cargo handling equipment, ballast (ballast may be loaded in ULDs), or Fly Away Kits,
For Passenger/Combi, one Lavatory/Galley fan is verified to be operative,
Aft Cargo Heat remains OFF,
If installed, humidifiers are operated manually,
If installed, Fwd Cargo Heat (electrical) is deactivated, and
If installed, the main cabin exhaust valve(s) is deactivated closed.

note.para: UPS does not carry Fly Away Kits in voided cargo compartments.
UPS -400F's and BCF's do not have humidifiers or cabin exhaust valves.
The following EICAS message(s) may remain displayed:

numlitem.para: &Ensuretheloadsupervisor;
Operation limited to two packs.
Extended overwater flight is prohibited.

para.revision: Extended Overwater operations is a horizontal distance of more than 50 NM from the nearest shoreline.

numlitem.para: Forward lower cargo and Main deck cargo compartment remains empty or contains only empty cargo handling equipment.

placard.para: Placard adjacent to Pack selector "ESC MISC CARD INOP - USE TWO PACKS MAX". Placard adjacent to AFT Cargo Heat Switch "DO NOT OPERATE - LEAVE AFT CARGO HT OFF". Install placard below Captain's PFD on P-1-1 panel "FORWARD CARGO COMP HEATING SYS INOP". Enter items in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Deactivate the forward overboard valve in the open position. Valve is located on the inside of the fuselage to the left of the nose gear wheel well.
Open and collar the P6 panel FWD OVBD VLV CONT and the P180 panel FWD OVBD VALVE POWER circuit breakers.
Disconnect, cap, and stow electrical connector DV462 from valve.
Manually position the operating lever/position indicator to the open position.
Lockwire lever to actuator mounting screws.
Deactivate forward cargo heat (electrical) per DMP 21-43-1.

item.title: Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Cabin Shutoff Valve(s)

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Associated pack is selected OFF,
Lower lobe cargo A/C FLOW RATE remains OFF, and
Associated Pack Flow Control & Shutoff Valve is secured closed.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ZONE TEMP

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals and perishables in associated cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard Lower Lobe Cargo Cond Air Flow Rate selector "LOWER LOBE CARGO A/C CABIN S/O VLV - INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Select discrepant pack to the OFF position. (Cargo A/C Forward Cabin Shutoff Valve – Pack 3; Cargo A/C Aft Cabin Shutoff Valve – Pack 2).
For an inoperative Lower Cargo A/C Forward Cabin Shutoff Valve secure Pack 3 Flow Control and Shutoff Valve closed as follows:
Position the associated Bleed Air Control panel (P5) PACK selector OFF.
Access valve through the air conditioning equipment bay access doors.
Manually rotate crank arm on end of butterfly shaft until valve is closed.
Run screw on end of crank into hole in the casting.

Manually select HI FLOW on remaining packs and advise crew that HI FLOW must remain selected to ensure that these packs will operate in High Flow Mode. The associated PACK ____ advisory message may be displayed.
If the affected Pack Flow Control and Shutoff Valve has an external maintenance canister installed containing a lockout device (a cap, a spring and a plug):

Remove the existing pack flow control and shutoff valve plug, packing, spring and filter from the inoperative Pack Flow Control and Shutoff Valve per AMM 21-51-13. Retain all removed parts for later storage in the canister.
Remove the perforated plug from the canister containing the lockout device (the canister is located near the end of the crank screw noted in step 1. D.).
Remove the cap and spring from inside the canister.
Install the cap and spring into the filter cavity: The small end of cap fits into the inside diameter of the spring. Ensure the cap is seated at the bottom of the filter cavity.
Apply anti-seize compound to the threads on the perforated plug obtained from the canister.
Install and tighten the perforated plug that was obtained from the canister: Tighten the plug to 60-70 pound-inches (6.78-7.90 newton-meters).
Install a lockwire on the perforated plug with the hole.
Place the removed plug, packing, spring and filter (from step 1. E. 1.) into the canister for storage and future restoration of the Pack Flow Control and Shutoff Valve function.
Position A/C Flow rate to HI FLOW on operative packs.
Position the Overhead Maintenance Panel (P461) CARGO COND AIR FLOW RATE selector to OFF.
For an inoperative Lower Cargo A/C Aft Cabin Shutoff Valve secure Pack 2 Flow Control and Shutoff Valve closed as follows:
Position the associated Bleed Air Control panel (P5) PACK selector OFF.
Access valve through the air conditioning equipment bay access doors.
Manually rotate crank arm on end of butterfly shaft until valve is closed.
Run screw on end of crank into hole in the casting.

Manually select HI FLOW on remaining packs and advise crew that HI FLOW must remain selected to ensure that these packs will operate in High Flow Mode. The associated PACK ____ advisory message may be displayed.
If the affected Pack Flow Control and Shutoff Valve has an external maintenance canister installed containing a lockout device (a cap, a spring and a plug):

Remove the existing pack flow control and shutoff valve plug, packing, spring and filter from the inoperative Pack Flow Control and Shutoff Valve per AMM 21-51-13. Retain all removed parts for later storage in the canister.
Remove the perforated plug from the canister containing the lockout device (the canister is located near the end of the crank screw noted in step 1. D.).
Remove the cap and spring from inside the canister.
Install the cap and spring into the filter cavity: The small end of cap fits into the inside diameter of the spring. Ensure the cap is seated at the bottom of the filter cavity.
Apply anti-seize compound to the threads on the perforated plug obtained from the canister.
Install and tighten the perforated plug that was obtained from the canister: Tighten the plug to 60-70 pound-inches (6.78-7.90 newton-meters).
Install a lockwire on the perforated plug with the hole.
Place the removed plug, packing, spring and filter (from step 1. E. 1.) into the canister for storage and future restoration of the Pack Flow Control and Shutoff Valve function.
Position A/C Flow rate to HI FLOW on operative packs.
Position the Overhead Maintenance Panel (P461) CARGO COND AIR FLOW RATE selector to OFF.

item.title: Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Cabin Shutoff Valve(s)

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Lower lobe cargo A/C FLOW RATE remains in OFF or LOW position, and
Associated valve is verified open.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ZONE TEMP
TEMP DEV CGO ___

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals and perishables in associated lower cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard Lower Lobe Cargo Cond Air Flow Rate selector "HIGH RATE INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Verify the associated Cargo A/C Cabin Shutoff Valve(s) are open by selecting the ECS Maintenance page on the CMC and observing that CABIN SOV POS indicates open (OP) for both LWR FWD and LWR AFT valves.
Position the Lower Lobe Cargo Cond Air Flow Rate selector to either LOW or OFF.

item.title: Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Cabin Shutoff Valve(s) – Valves Secured Open

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided associated valve is secured open.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ZONE TEMP

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals and perishables in associated cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard Lower Lobe Cargo Cond Air Flow Rate selector "HIGH RATE INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.title: LOWER LOBE CARGO A/C CABIN SHUTOFF VALVE(S)

numlitem.para: Open associated circuit breaker(s);
For aft valve, open the P414 panel LOWER AFT CARGO AIR COND VLVS circuit breaker.
For forward valve, open the P414 panel LOWER FORWARD CARGO AIR COND VLVS circuit breaker.
Secure discrepant Lower A/C Cargo Forward Shutoff Valve or lower Aft A/C Cabin Shutoff Valve in the open position.

Locate Forward A/C Cargo Cabin Shutoff Valve (Pack 3) in the right body wheel well; STA 1261, WL 167, RBL 28. Manually position valve in the open position. Remove, cap, and stow valve electrical connector.
Locate Aft A/C Cargo Cabin Shutoff Valve (Pack 2) under main deck floor; STA 1245, WL 180, LBL 17. Manually position valve in the open position. Remove, cap, and stow valve electrical connector.
Position the LOWER LOBE CARGO COND AIR FLOW RATE selector to OFF or LOW on the overhead Maintenance panel (P461).
Close LOWER FORWARD CARGO AIR COND VLVS and LOWER AFT CARGO AIR COND VLVS circuit breakers on the P414 panel.
In the cockpit the Status message ZONE TEMP will remain displayed.

graphic.title: LOWER LOBE CARGO A/C CABIN SHUTOFF VALVE(S)

item.title: Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Trim Shutoff Valve(s) – Valve Secured Closed

remarks.para: May be inoperative secured closed.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ZONE TEMP

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals and perishables in associated lower cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard Lower Lobe Cargo Cond Air Flow Rate selector "LOW or HIGH". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.title: LOWER LOBE CARGO A/C TRIM SHUTOFF VALVE(S)

numlitem.para: Open LOWER FORWARD CARGO AIR COND VLVS and LOWER AFT CARGO AIR COND VLVS circuit breakers on the P414 panel.
Secure lower Lobe Cargo Trim Air Shutoff Valve(s) in closed position as follows:

For Fwd Cargo Trim Air Shutoff Valve, remove the AFT right air conditioning equipment bay panel 192MR to access valve (STA 1240, WL 79, RBL 104). Manually position valve in the closed position. Remove, cap, and stow valve electrical connector.

For AFT Cargo Trim Air Shutoff Valve, locate valve in right body landing gear wheel well on inboard bulkhead (STA 1435, WL 140, RBL 7). Manually position valve in closed position. Remove, cap, and stow valve electrical connector.
Close LOWER FORWARD CARGO AIR COND VLV and LOWER AFT CARGO AIR COND VLVS circuit breakers on the P414 panel.
In the cockpit the Status message ZONE TEMP will remain displayed.

item.title: Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Trim Modulating Valve(s)

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided associated valve is secured closed.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ZONE TEMP
Trim air is not available to the conditioned air supplied to the compartment.

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals and perishables in associated lower cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard associated Lower Lobe Temp selector "TRIM AIR INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: To secure Fwd Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Trim Modulating Valve closed:
Open the P6 panel ZONE TEMP CONT AC and ZONE TEMP CONT DC circuit breakers.
Remove the aft right hand air conditioning equipment bay panel 192MR to access forward cargo trim air Modulation valve (STA 1208, WL 100, RBL 105).
Disconnect, cap, and stow valve’s electrical connector.
Manually position the valve in the closed position (requires an Allen wrench).
Close the P6 panel ZONE TEMP CONT AC and ZONE TEMP CONT DC circuit breakers
In the cockpit the Status message ZONE TEMP will remain displayed.
To secure Aft Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Trim Modulating Valve closed:
Open the P6 panel ZONE TEMP CONT AC and ZONE TEMP CONT DC circuit breakers.
Locate Aft Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Trim Modulating Valve located in right body landing gear wheel well on inboard bulkhead (STA 1436, WL 155, RBL 7).
Disconnect, cap, and stow valve’s electrical connector.
Manually position the valve in the closed position (will require an Allen wrench).
Close the P6 panel ZONE TEMP CONT AC and ZONE TEMP CONT DC circuit breakers.
In the cockpit the Status message ZONE TEMP will remain displayed.

item.title: Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Trim Modulating Valve(s)

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided associated Lower Cargo Trim Shutoff Valve is secured closed.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ZONE TEMP
Trim air is not available to the conditioned air supplied to the compartment.

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals and perishables in associated lower cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard associated Lower Lobe Temp selector "TRIM AIR INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: To secure Lower Lobe FWD Cargo A/C Trim Shutoff Valve closed:
Open LOWER FORWARD CARGO AIR COND VLVS and LOWER AFT CARGO AIR COND VLVS circuit breakers on the P414 panel.
For Fwd Cargo Trim Air Shutoff Valve, remove the AFT right air conditioning equipment bay panel 192MR to access valve (STA 1240, WL 79, RBL 104).
Manually position valve in the closed position. Remove, cap, and stow valve electrical connector.
Open LOWER FORWARD CARGO AIR COND VLVS and LOWER AFT CARGO AIR COND VLVS circuit breakers on the P414 panel.
In the cockpit the Stats message ZONE TEMP may remain displayed.
To secure Lower Lobe AFT Cargo A/C Trim Shutoff Valve closed:
Open LOWER FORWARD CARGO AIR COND VLVS and LOWER AFT CARGO COND VLVS circuit breakers on the P414 panel.
For AFT Cargo Trim Air Shutoff Valve, locate valve in right body landing gear wheel well on inboard bulkhead (STA 1435, WL 140, RBL 7).
Manually position valve in closed position. Remove, cap, and stow valve electrical connector.
Close LOWER FORWARD CARGO AIR COND VLVS and LOWER AFT CARGO AIR COND VLVS circuit breakers on the P414 panel.
In the cockpit the Status message ZONE TEMP may remain displayed.

remarks.para: May be inoperative closed.

note.para: A closed flapper valve (due to the change in airflow) may cause odors from the AFT Lower Lobe cargo compartment to enter the main cargo deck and/or the upper deck.

placard.para: Placard "AFT CARGO A/C FLAPPER VLV(s) INOP" below Captain's PFD ON P-1-1 panel. Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Open the P6 panel FIRE EXTINGUISHER CARGO and FIRE EXTINGUISHER MN DK CARGO circuit breakers.
Position the Fire Control panel (P5) CARGO FIRE AFT switch to the armed position.
Remove screws (4 places) holding screen over flapper valve(s) and remove screen.

warning.para: THE NEXT STEP WILL CAUSE THE CARGO FLAPPER VALVE DOOR TO CLOSE. KEEP HANDS CLEAR OF DOOR.

numlitem.para: Push the RESET switch on the flapper valve assembly(s).
Position the Fire Control panel (P5) CARGO FIRE AFT switch to the OFF position.
Close the P6 panel FIRE EXTINGUISHER CARGO and FIRE EXTINGUISHER MN DK CARGO circuit breaker.
Re-install screen(s) over flapper valve(s).

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
CARGO ZONE TEMP

When a Cargo Temperature Selector is inoperative, zone temperature controllers automatically default to a target of 60°F for the associated zone. If the temperature selector's MAN mode remains available, associated zone temperature other than 60 may be obtained by selecting MAN and then W (warmer) or C (cooler) as desired to move the associated trim air mod valve. Cargo compartment temperatures are available on the ECS synoptics page.

numlitem.para: If Manual Mode is not available, carriage of animals and perishables in associated cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard associated Cargo Temperature selector "TEMPERATURE SELECTOR INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Lower Lobe Cargo A/C FLOW RATE Selector

remarks.para: May be inoperative selected OFF.

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals and perishables in associated lower cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard Lower Lobe Cargo Cond Air Flow Rate selector "INOP - LEAVE OFF". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Position the Overhead Maintenance panel (P461) LOWER LOBE CARGO COND AIR FLOW RATE Selector OFF.
Select the ECS Maintenance page on the CMC and:
Confirm Cabin SOV POS indicates open (OP) for LWR FWD and LWR AFT valves.
Confirm FRV POSITION indicates closed (0.0) for LWR FWD and LWR AFT valves.

item.title: Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Duct Overheat Protective System

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided associated Cargo A/C Trim SOV is secured closed.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
CARGO ZONE TEMP

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals and perishables in associated lower cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard Lower Lobe Cargo Cond Air Flow Rate selector "INOP -- LEAVE OFF". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Open LOWER FORWARD CARGO AIR COND VLVS and LOWER AFT CARGO AIR COND VLVS circuit breakers on the P414 panel.
Secure lower Lobe Cargo Trim Air Shutoff Valve(s) in closed position as follows:

For Fwd Cargo Trim Air Shutoff Valve, remove the AFT right air conditioning equipment bay panel 192MR to access valve (STA 1240, WL 79, RBL 104). Manually position valve in the closed position. Remove, cap, and stow valve electrical connector.

For AFT Cargo Trim Air Shutoff Valve, locate valve in right body landing gear wheel well on inboard bulkhead (STA 1435, WL 140, RBL 7). Manually position valve in closed position. Remove, cap, and stow valve electrical connector.
Close LOWER FORWARD CARGO AIR COND VLVS and LOWER AFT CARGO AIR COND VLVS circuit breakers on the P414 panel.
In the cockpit the Status message ZONE TEMP will remain displayed.

item.title: Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Duct Overheat Protective System

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided associated Cargo A/C Trim Modulating valve is secured closed.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
CARGO ZONE TEMP

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals and perishables in associated lower cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard Lower Lobe Cargo Cond Air Flow Rate selector "TRIM AIR INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: To secure Fwd Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Trim Modulating Valve closed:
Open the P6 panel ZONE TEMP CONT AC and ZONE TEMP CONT DC circuit breakers.
Remove the aft right hand air conditioning equipment bay panel 192MR to access forward cargo trim air Modulation valve (STA 1208, WL 100, RBL 105).
Disconnect, cap, and stow valve’s electrical connector.
Manually position the valve in the closed position (requires an Allen wrench).
Close the P6 panel ZONE TEMP CONT AC and ZONE TEMP CONT DC circuit breakers.
In the cockpit the Status message ZONE TEMP may remain displayed.
To secure Aft Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Trim Modulating Valve closed:
Open the P6 panel ZONE TEMP CONT AC and ZONE TEMP CONT DC circuit breakers.
Locate Aft Lower Lobe Cargo A/C Trim Modulating Valve located in right body landing gear wheel well on inboard bulkhead (STA 1436, WL 155, RBL 7).
Disconnect, cap, and stow valve’s electrical connector.
Manually position the valve in the closed position (require an Allen wrench).
Close the P6 panel ZONE TEMP CONT AC and ZONE TEMP CONT DC circuit breakers.
In the cockpit the Status message ZONE TEMP may remain displayed.

item.title: Aft Cargo A/C Underfloor Heat Control Switch – (32°F Switch)

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided AFT CARGO HT remains OFF during cargo conditioning operations.

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals and perishables in associated cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard AFT CARGO Heat switch "LEAVE OFF". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard "LOWER LOBE CARGO VENT FAN(s) INOP" below Captain's PFD on P-1-1 panel. Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Lower Lobe Cargo Flow Regulating Valves

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Associated valve is secured closed, and
Lower lobe cargo A/C FLOW RATE for the associated cargo compartment is not selected.
Carriage of animals and perishables in associated lower cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard Lower Lobe Cargo Con Air Flow Rate selector "FWD or AFT INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: To secure Forward Cargo Air Conditioning Flow Regulating Valve closed:
Open the P6 panel ZONE TEMP CONT AC and ZONE TEMP CONT DC circuit breakers.
Locate Forward Cargo Flow Air Conditioning Regulating Valve located in Pack 3 bay at STA 1200, WL 101, RBL 44.
Disconnect, cap, and stow valve’s electrical connector.
Manually position the valve in the closed position (requires an Allen wrench).
Close the P6 panel ZONE TEMP CONT AC and ZONE TEMP CONT DC circuit breakers.
Position the Overhead Maintenance panel (P461) LOWER LOBE CARGO COND FLOW RATE selector to HIGH AFT or LOW AFT or OFF.
To secure Aft Cargo Flow Air Conditioning Regulating Valve closed:
Open the P6 panel ZONE TEMP CONT AC and ZONE TEMP CONT DC circuit breakers.
Locate Aft Cargo Flow Air Conditioning Regulating Valve located in main wing gear wheel well at STA 1324, WL 175, RBL 19.
Disconnect, cap, and stow valve’s electrical connector.
Manually position the valve in the closed position (require an Allen wrench).
Close the P6 panel ZONE TEMP CONT AC and ZONE TEMP CONT DC circuit breakers.
Position the Overhead Maintenance panel (P461) LOWER LOBE CARGO COND FLOW RATE selector to HIGH FWD or LOW FWD or OFF.

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Associated valve is secured closed, and
Lower lobe cargo A/C FLOW RATE is selected to either LOW or HIGH.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
MN DK SOV ___

placard.para: Placard Lower Lobe Cargo Con air Flow Rate selector "MAIN DECK S/O VLV INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Secure the associated Main Deck Shutoff Valve (M/D SOV) in the closed position by accessing the affected M/D SOV located under the main deck floor panels forward of wing gear wheel well in the mix bay:
Remove cargo-handling hardware, as required, to access the applicable floor panels.
Remove floor panels that are over affected M/D SOV at the following locations:
Open the P7 panel MN/DK FIRE SOV CONT circuit breaker.
Open the following P414 panel circuit breaker for the failed valve:
For M/D SOV 1, open the MN DK FIRE AIR COND SOV – 1 circuit breaker.
For M/D SOV 2, open the MN DK FIRE AIR COND SOV – 2 circuit breaker.
For M/D SOV 3, open the MN DK FIRE AIR COND SOV – 3 circuit breaker.
For M/D SOV 4, open the MN DK FIRE AIR COND SOV – 4 circuit breaker.
For M/D SOV 5, open the MN DK FIRE AIR COND SOV – 5 circuit breaker.
Disconnect, cap, and stow the electrical connector from the affected valve.
Manually position the valve override handle in the closed position.
Reinstall previously removed floor panels.
Reinstall previously removed cargo handling hardware.
Close the P7 panel MN/DK FIRE SOV CONT circuit breaker (step C) and the circuit breaker opened in step D above.
Position the Overhead Maintenance panel (P461) LOWER LOBE CARGO CON AIR FLOW RATE selector to either LOW or HIGH.

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Associated valve is secured closed, and
One pack remains OFF.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
MN DK SOV
PACK ___

numlitem.para: Carriage of animals and perishables in lower cargo compartments is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard Lower Lobe Cargo Cond Air Flow Rate selector on Overhead Maintenance panel (P461) "INOP OFF" and "MAIN DECK S/O VLV INOP". Placard adjacent to associated Pack selector "INOP OFF" and "PACK ___ FLOW CONTROL AND SHUTOFF VALVE INOP CLOSED" Enter items in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Secure the associated Main Deck Shutoff Valve (M/D SOV) in the closed position by accessing the affected M/D SOV located under the main deck floor panels forward of wing gear wheel well in the mix bay:
Remove cargo-handling hardware, as required, to access the applicable floor panels.
Remove floor panels that are over affect M/D SOV at the following locations:
Open the P7 panel MN/DK FIRE SOV CONT circuit breaker.
Open the following P414 panel circuit breaker for the failed valve:
For M/D SOV 1, open the MN DK FIRE AIR COND SOV – 1 circuit breaker.
For M/D SOV 2, open the MN DK FIRE AIR COND SOV – 2 circuit breaker.
For M/D SOV 3, open the MN DK FIRE AIR COND SOV – 3 circuit breaker.
For M/D SOV 4, open the MN DK FIRE AIR COND SOV – 4 circuit breaker.
For M/D SOV 5, open the MN DK FIRE AIR COND SOV – 5 circuit breaker.
Disconnect, cap, and stow the electrical connector from the affected valve.
Manually position the valve override handle in the closed position.
Reinstall previously removed floor panels.
Reinstall previously removed cargo handling hardware.
Close the P7 panel MN/DK FIRE SOV CONT circuit breaker (step C) and the circuit breaker opened in step D above.
Position the associated Bleed Air Control panel (P5) PACK selector OFF.
Secure the affected Pack Flow Control and Shutoff Valve closed:
Access valve through the air conditioning equipment bay access doors.
Manually rotate crank arm on end of butterfly shaft until valve is closed.
Run screw on end of crank into hole in the casting.
For failure of FCSOV closed limit switch (switch will not close):

note.para: The shorting wire and plug in the following steps is UPS P/N 747-21-002-101, if available.

numlitem.para: Fabricate a 3 to 4 inch shorting wire from 20 to 24 SWG type 6A (BMS 13-60 Type 1 or BMS 13-48 Type 10) wire and two P/N BACC47CN1 (or P/N BACC47CN1S) pin contacts.
Obtain shorting plug P/N BACC45FN12-12P and, using fabricated shorting wire, short pin numbers 1 & 2 on the shorting plug.
Disconnect electrical connector from the FCSOV.
Install shorting plug, P/N BACC45FN12-12P, with shorting wire attached, on the electrical connector and stow.
Position the overhead Maintenance panel (P461) LOWER CARGO COND AIR FLOW RATE selector to OFF.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Main Deck Shutoff Valves are verified to be operative before each flight,
Pack Dump Valves are verified to be operative before each flight, and
Forward lower lobe cargo A/C FLOW RATE is not selected.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ECS FRTR CARD

numlitem.para: Observe LIMITATIONS/PERFORMANCE PENALTIES.
Carriage of animals and perishables is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard Lower Lobe Cargo Cond Air Flow Rate selector "FWD INOP - OFF". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

note.para: The repetitive inspection required when this item is inoperative must be documented in the Aircraft Logbook at the prescribed intervals. (Refer to GMM, Chapter 3, Section 6.)

numlitem.para: Position the Overhead Maintenance panel (P461) LOWER LOBE CARGO COND AIR FLOW RATE SELECTOR to AFT LOW or AFT HIGH or OFF.
Verify Main deck Shut Off Valves (M/C SOVs) and Pack Dump Valves are operative by performing the following steps:
Ensure the Cargo Fire Main Deck Arm Switch is not ARMED.
Position the Bleed Air Control panel (P5) PACK 1 selector to NORM and Pack 2 and 3 Selectors to OFF.
Access Pack 1 flow Control Valve through the air conditioning equipment bay access doors and disconnect connector DV93 from the valve (V93).
Access L – MAIN EQPT/E1-1 THROUGH E1-6 disconnect panel number AE 0411 (STA 450, WL 180, LBL 50) and disconnect the cap from connector D40823J.
Verify pins 1, 3, 5, 7, and 9 on connector D40823J are grounded.

note.para: Pins on connector D40823J (limit switch contacts), when grounded, verify the associated valves’ position as follows:

numlitem.para: Verify pins 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 on connector D40823J are not grounded.

Access Pack 1 Dump Valve (V556) and Pack 3 Dump Valve (V557) through the air conditioning equipment bay access doors and visually verify BOTH valves are OPEN as shown by the valve’s position indicators.
Position the Fire control panel (P5) CARGO FIRE MAIN DECK switch to ARMED.
Verify pins 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 on connector D40823J are grounded.
Verify pins 1, 3, 5, 7, and 9 on connector D40823J are not grounded.
Visually verify that the Pack 1 Dump Valve (V556) is CLOSED.
Visually verify that the Pack 3 Dump valve (V557) is OPEN.
Reconnect connector DV93 to the Pack 1 Flow Control Valve (V93).
Position the Bleed Air Control panel (P5) PACK 1 selector OFF and PACK 3 selector NORM.
Disconnect connector DV95 from Pack 3 Control Valve (V95).
Visually verify that the Pack 1 Dump Valve (V556) is OPEN.
Visually verify that the Pack 3 Dump Valve (V557) is CLOSED.
Reconnect connector DV95 to the Pack 3 Flow Control Valve (V95).
Position the Bleed Air Control panel (P5) PACK 3 selector OFF.
Position the Fire Control panel (P5) CARGO FIRE MAIN DECK switch OFF.
Verify pins 1, 3, 5, 7, and 9 on connector D40823J are grounded.
Verify pins 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 on connector D40823J are not grounded.
Reconnect the cap to connector D40823J at the L-MAIN EQPT/E1-1 THROUGH E1-6 disconnect panel number AEO411.

remarks.para: One valve may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: A maximum of two packs are used throughout flight,
Valve is deactivated closed, and
Both automatic and manual controls are operative on the remaining valve.

note.para: The carriage of animals or perishables is dependent on Pack availability or configuration.
The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
OUTFLOW VALVE ___

numlitem.para: Packs 2 and 3 provide conditioned air to forward and aft lower lobe cargo compartments.
If pack 2 is not used, the aft lower lobe cargo compartment may still be heated by the aft cargo heating system.
If pack 3 is not used, the forward lower lobe cargo compartment may still be heated to a limited extent by the equipment cooling exhaust air.
Operation limited to two packs.
Carriage of animals and perishables in associated lower cargo compartment is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard associated Manual Outflow Valve switch "OUTFLOW VLV INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Deactivate left or right outflow valve closed as detailed below:
For the left outflow valve, open and collar P6 panel CABIN PRESS CONT L ICU circuit breaker. Also on the P414 panel, open and collar CABIN PRESS CONT ICU Left circuit breaker.
For the right outflow valve, open and collar P6 panel CABIN PRESS CONT R ICU circuit breaker. Also on the P414 panel, open and collar CABIN PRESS CONT ICU RIGHT circuit breaker.
Determine position of inoperative outflow valve. If not fully closed, manually close by one of the following methods:
If manual control is available:
Select manual control for the affected outflow valve (MAN L or MAN R ON), and drive affected outflow valve fully closed.
Deselect manual control (MAN L or MAN R OFF).
If manual control is not available:
Remove outflow valve AC motor (AMM 21-31-06/401).

note.para: Caution should be taken so as not to lose AC motor shim plate.

numlitem.para: Close valve by applying torque to actuator output shaft.
Reinstall AC motor.

item.chgdesc: Adds Note in Limitations.
item.title: Outflow Valves

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Flight is conducted in an unpressurized configuration,

Procedures are established and used to verify main deck and lower lobe cargo compartments remain empty or contain only empty cargo handling equipment, ballast (ballast may be loaded in ULDs), or Fly Away Kits,
Extended overwater flight is prohibited, and

Crew rests, crew workstations and passenger business centers with a door and smoke detection system (except the Combi Enlarged Lav/Business Center) are empty, locked closed and placard INOPERATIVE - DO NOT ENTER.

note.para: UPS does not carry Fly Away Kits in voided cargo compartments.
The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
OUTFLOW VALVE ___

numlitem.para: &Ensuretheloadsupervisor;
With supernumeraries on board, en route altitude must be limited to 10,000 feet.
Equipment cooling may be operated in NORM or STBY.

If operation with Equipment Cooling in OVRD mode becomes necessary inflight, an unpressurized configuration yields insufficient equipment cooling. Flight time must therefore be limited to 60 minutes when in OVRD mode.
A minimum of two pack operation is required for unpressurized flight.
Flight will be unpressurized.
Flight is limited to an en route altitude of 10,000 feet with supernumeraries on board.
Main cargo deck and lower cargo holds remain empty, or contain only empty cargo handling equipment.
Flight must be within 60 minutes of a suitable airport.
Extended overwater flight is prohibited.

para.revision: Extended Overwater operations is a horizontal distance of more than 50 NM from the nearest shoreline.

numlitem.para: Crew rests area is empty, and secured closed.

placard.para: Placard associated Manual Outflow Valve "OUTFLOW VLVS INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log. Placard the Upper Deck Crew Rest - "COMPARTMENT INOPERATIVE - DO NOT ENTER".

para.emphasis: BOTH OUTFLOW VALVES INOPERATIVE - UNPRESSURIZED FLIGHT

numlitem.para: Deactivate both left and right outflow valves open as detailed below:
Open and collar P6 panel CABIN PRESS CONT L ICU and CABIN PRESS CONT R ICU circuit breakers.
Open and collar P414 panel CABIN PRESS ICU LEFT and CABIN PRESS ICU RIGHT circuit breakers.
Determine position of both outflow valves. If not fully open, manually open by one of the following methods:
If manual control is available:
Select outflow valves to manual control (MAN L or MAN R ON), and drive valves fully open.
Deselect manual control (MAN L or MAN R OFF).
If manual control is not available:
Remove AC motor from both outflow valves per (AMM 21-31-06/401).

note.para: Caution should be taken so as not to lose AC motor shim plate.

numlitem.para: Open valves by applying torque to actuator output shaft.
Reinstall AC motor.
Check that the upper Deck Crew Rest (Freighter) compartment is empty, locked closed.

item.title: Automatic Cabin Pressure Controllers (A and B)

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided both outflow valves are operative in manual mode.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
CABIN ALT AUTO ___

placard.para: Placard Cabin Pressurization Controller Selector "MODE A or MODE B INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Automatic Cabin Pressure Controllers (A and B)

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: If one outflow valve is inoperative in the manual mode, it must be deactivated closed, with a maximum of two packs used throughout flight, and
Cabin altitude backup sensor system (CPCS BACKUP SENS) is operative.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
CABIN ALT AUTO ___

numlitem.para: Packs 2 and 3 provide conditioned air to forward and aft lower lobe cargo compartments.
If pack 2 is not used, the aft lower lobe cargo compartment may still be heated by the aft cargo heating system.
If pack 3 is not used, the forward lower lobe cargo compartment may still be heated to a limited extent by the equipment cooling exhaust air.
Maximum of two packs used throughout flight.
Carriage of animals and perishables in lower cargo compartments is prohibited.

placard.para: Placard Cabin Pressurization Controller Selector "MODE A INOP or MODE B INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.title: OUTFLOW VALVES
maintenance.para: ONE OUTFLOW VALVE INOPERATIVE

numlitem.para: Deactivate left or right outflow valve closed as detailed below:
For the left outflow valve, open and collar the P6 panel CABIN PRESS CONT L ICU and P414 panel CABIN PRESS ICU LEFT circuit breakers.
For the right outflow valve, open and collar the P6 panel CABIN PRESS CONT R ICU and P414 panel CABIN PRESS ICU RIGHT circuit breakers.
Determine position of inoperative outflow valve. If not fully closed, manually close by one of the following methods:
If manual control is available:
