placard.para: Placard inoperative Audio Control Panel "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Install "INOP" placards on: a) Nose Cargo Door Loadmaster panel, b) Side Cargo Door Loadmaster panel, c) All 3 audio control panels, and d) the "CALL" module CARGO pushbutton (on pedestal). Enter items in Aircraft Deferred item Log.

item.title: Captain/First Officer Push-to-Talk (PTT) Switches – Control Wheel PTT Switches

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Associated audio control panel PTT switch is operative, and
Affected switch is deactivated open.

placard.para: Placard affected Control Wheel Medallion "PTT SW INOP OPEN" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Deactivate the affected control wheel PTT switch open.
Open the P7 panel INTERPHONE – CAP and INTERPHONE – F/O circuit breakers.
Remove the two screws which mount the PTT switch into the control wheel.
Remove the PTT switch assembly to gain access to the wires.
Disconnect the terminal lugs from the switch.
Cap the wires and stow them in the control wheel horn.
Install the PTT switch assembly in the control wheel and secure with the two screws.
Close the P7 panel INTERPHONE – CAPT and INTERPHONE – F/O circuit breakers.

item.title: Captain/First Officer Push-to-Talk (PTT) Switches – Flight Crew Audio Control Panel PTT Switches

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Associated control wheel PTT switch is operative, and
Affected switch is verified inoperative open.

placard.para: Placard affected Panel PTT switch "PTT SW INOP OPEN" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Verify that the affected ACP PTT switch is inoperative open.
Push the PA transmitter select switch on the associated ACP and ensure the PA MIC light is illuminated.
Without pressing any PTT, speak into the associated microphone and determine if voice transmission can be heard over the PA system. If no voice is heard, the switch is in the open position.

item.title: Captain/First Officer Push-to-Talk (PTT) Switches – Glareshield PTT Switches

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided the affected switch is deactivated open.

placard.para: Placard affected Glareshield PTT switch "PTT SW INOP OPEN" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Deactivate the affected glareshield PTT switch open.
Open the P7 panel INTERPHONE – CAPT and INTERPHONE – F/O circuit breakers.
Remove the screws which mount the glareshield panel containing the affected PTT switch.
Remove the glareshield panel to gain access to the PTT wires.
Disconnect the wires from the PTT switch.
Cap the wires and stow them behind the switch panel.
Install the glareshield panel and secure with its mounting screws.
Close the P7 panel INTERPHONE - CAPT and INTERPHONE - F/O circuit breakers.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Flight Data Recorder (FDR) is operative, and
Repairs are made within three flight days.

placard.para: Placard Cockpit Voice Recorder System "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.chgdesc: Adds EICAS message to Note in Operations Procedure for company necessity.
item.title: ENGINE DRIVEN GENERATOR SYSTEMS (IDG, GCU, GCB)

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Generator Control Breaker (GCB), if inoperative, remains open,
For PW, if engine Air Oil Cooler (AOC) is operative, fuel tank temperature remains above -36°C throughout the flight, and
IDG is disconnected or removed.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
DRIVE DISC ___
ELEC DRIVE ___
DRIVE ___ TEMP SNS
ELEC GEN SYS ___

para.revision: ELEC GEN OFF ___

placard.para: Placard affected GEN control switch "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.para: Use the following procedures to verify the IDG is disconnected, and deactivate the Integrated Drive Generator (IDG) when an IDG, Generator Control Unit (GCU), or Generator Control Breaker (GCB) system failure condition is indicated:

numlitem.para: If EICAS status message DRIVE DISC ___, indicating the IDG is positively disconnected, is not already displayed, do the following procedure to disconnect the IDG:
Apply APU or external power if not already accomplished (AMM 24-22-00/201).
Verify BATTERY switch, located on P5 overhead panel, is ON.
Verify STANDBY POWER switch, located on P5 overhead panel, is in AUTO position.
Position applicable GEN CONT switch, located on P5 overhead panel, to OFF.
Verify all BUS TIE switches, located on P5 overhead panel, are in AUTO and the BUS TIE ISLN lights are extinguished.

If associated failed GCB’s BUS TIE breaker ISLN light is illuminated with all BUS tie switches set to AUTO position, and both synchronous buses are powered, this indicates a failed closed generator control breaker. Dispatch is not allowed.
Start applicable engine (AMM 71-00-00/201).

caution.para: THE REMAINING PORTION OF THIS PROCEDURE SHOULD BE ACCOMPLISHED WITH THE APPLICABLE ENGINE RUNNING TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE DRIVE DISCONNECT ASSEMBLY.
DO NOT DEPRESS IDG DRIVE DISCONNECT SWITCH WHEN SPEED IS BELOW MINIMUM IDLE RPM. IDG MAY BE DAMAGED AS A RESULT OF AN INCOMPLETE DISCONNECT.

numlitem.para: With applicable engine operating at idle rpm or above, pull guard on appropriate IDG DRIVE DISC switch and momentarily depress switch.
Observe DRIVE light, on DRIVE DISC switch, is illuminated.

Verify applicable EICAS advisory message >DRIVE DISC ___ is displayed on the EICAS display. If the DRIVE DISC___ message is not displayed with the aircraft on the ground, then remove the IDG per step 2 below.
Restore aircraft to required configuration.

caution.para: IF THE ENGINE OPERATES WITH THE IDG DISCONNECTED FOR MORE THAN 50 HOURS, THEN THE IDG INPUT SHAFT BALL BEARING ASSEMBLY SHOULD BE REMOVED AND SHOP INSPECTED FOR WEAR.

numlitem.para: If IDG fails to disconnect then the following removal procedure will need to be followed:
Remove the inoperative IDG from gearbox (AMM 24-11-01/401).
Ensure aircraft weight and balance information includes removal of the IDG. IDG weight and balance arm data is:

entry.para: Removed IDG Weight & Balance Arm Data

numlitem.para: For GE engines, the following procedure may be used to install IDG shaft plug and secure for dispatch, using deactivation/dispatch KIT G24005-24:
Install IDG shaft plug:
Lubricate O-ring with engine oil.
Install plug into IDG drive spline on accessory gearbox and tighten plug nut.
Install IDG drive pad cover plate.
Place cover plate into the IDG Quick Attach-Detach (QAD) ring.
Tighten IDG QAD ring tension bolt to 240-264 pound-inches (27.1-29.8 N-m).
Using a soft mallet, firmly tap the edge of the QAD ring.

note.para: Tap ring only from 4 o'clock to 7 o'clock position, viewing from rear with tension bolt on left side.

numlitem.para: Re-tighten IDG QAD ring tension bolt same as step b) and install lockwire.
Connect the following on the IDG drive pad cover plate:
4 generator power cables to the dummy terminal studs.
2 electrical connectors to the dummy receptacles.
Over temperature drain tube, with bolt and cap. Install cap lockwire to the lug on cover plate.
Oil-in and oil-out tubes: Install tube assembly and tighten couplings on tubes. Clamp tube assembly to bracket on cover plate.
Close the left thrust reverser half (AMM 78-31-00/201).

item.chgdesc: Adds EICAS message to Note in Operations Procedure for company necessity.
item.title: ENGINE DRIVEN GENERATOR SYSTEMS (IDG, GCU, GCB) – IDG REMOVED

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Generator Control Breaker (GCB), if inoperative, remains open,
For PW, if engine Air Oil Cooler (AOC) is operative, fuel tank temperature remains above -36°C throughout the flight, and
IDG is removed.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
DRIVE DISC ___
ELEC DRIVE ___
DRIVE ___ TEMP SNS
ELEC GEN SYS ___

para.revision: ELEC GEN OFF ___

placard.para: Placard affected GEN control switch "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.title: ENGINE DRIVEN GENERATOR SYSTEMS (IDG, GCU, GCB)
maintenance.para: Use the following procedures to deactivate the Integrated Drive Generator (IDG) when an IDG, Generator Control Unit (GCU), or Generator Control Breaker (GCB) system failure condition is indicated:

numlitem.para: If EICAS status message DRIVE DISC ___, indicating the IDG is positively disconnected, is not already displayed, do the following procedure to disconnect the IDG:
Apply APU or external power if not already accomplished (AMM 24-22-00/201).
Verify BATTERY switch, located on P5 overhead panel, is ON.
Verify STANDBY POWER switch, located on P5 overhead panel, is in AUTO position.
Position applicable GEN CONT switch, located on P5 overhead panel, to OFF.
Verify all BUS TIE switches, located on P5 overhead panel, are in AUTO and the BUS TIE ISLN lights are extinguished.

If associated failed GCB’s BUS TIE breaker ISLN light is illuminated with all BUS tie switches set to AUTO position, and both synchronous buses are powered, this indicates a failed closed generator control breaker. Dispatch is not allowed.
Start applicable engine (AMM 71-00-00/201).

caution.para: The remaining portion of this procedure should be accomplished with the applicable engine running to prevent damage to the drive disconnect assembly.
Do not depress IDG drive disconnect switch when speed is below minimum idle rpm. IDG may be damaged as a result of a incomplete disconnect.

numlitem.para: With applicable engine operating at idle rpm or above, pull guard on appropriate IDG DRIVE DISC switch and momentarily depress switch.
Observe DRIVE light, on DRIVE DISC switch, is illuminated.

Verify applicable EICAS advisory message >DRIVE DISC_ is displayed on the EICAS display. If the >DRIVE DISC_ message is not displayed with the aircraft on the ground, then remove the IDG per step 2 below.
Restore aircraft to required configuration.

caution.para: If the engine operates with the IDG disconnected for more than 50 hours, then the IDG input shaft ball bearing assembly should be removed and shop inspected for wear.

numlitem.para: If IDG fails to disconnect then the following removal procedure will need to be followed:
Remove the inoperative IDG from gearbox (AMM 24-11-01/401).
Ensure aircraft weight and balance information includes removal of the IDG. IDG weight and balance arm data is:

entry.para: Removed IDG Weight & Balance Arm Data

numlitem.para: For GE engines, the following procedure may be used to install IDG shaft plug and secure for dispatch, using deactivation/dispatch kit G24005-24:
Install IDG shaft plug:
Lubricate O-ring with engine oil.
Install plug into IDG drive spline on accessory gearbox and tighten plug nut.
Install IDG drive pad cover plate.
Place cover plate into the IDG Quick Attach-Detach (QAD) ring.
Tighten IDG QAD ring tension bolt to 240-264 pound-inches (27.1-29.8 N-m).
Using a soft mallet, firmly tap the edge of the QAD ring.

note.para: Tap ring only from 4 o’clock to 7 o’clock position, viewing from rear with tension bolt on left side.

numlitem.para: Re-tighten IDG QAD ring tension bolt same as step b) and install lockwire.
Connect the following on the IDG drive pad cover plate:
4 generator power cables to the dummy terminal studs.
2 electrical connectors to the dummy receptacles.
Over temperature drain tube, with bolt and cap. Install cap lockwire to the lug on cover plate.
Oil-in and oil-out tubes: Install tube assembly and tighten couplings on tubes. Clamp tube assembly to bracket on cover plate.
Close the left thrust reverser half (AMM 78-31-00/201).

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard affected Gen DRIVE light "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: One of each phase may be inoperative provided all AC buses are paralleled.

note.para: For triple channel autoland at least two of the three generators used must have lightning protection on all three phases.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "LIGHTNING PROTECTOR(s) INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: APU Drive Generator Systems (Generator, AGCU, APB) – (APB's) Remains Open

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided associated Auxiliary Power Breaker(s) (APBs) remains open.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
APU GEN ___
When dispatching with APU Gen 1 inop turn #4 DEMAND PUMP to AUTO for pushback, #4 AUX inop due to Gnd Handling bus not powered.
If EEC CLNG SUP FAN status message is displayed, it can be cleared by rotating the EQUIP COOLING switch to OVRD, then back to NORM.

placard.para: Placard APU GEN Switch "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.title: APU DRIVE GENERATOR SYSTEMS (GENERATOR, AGCU, APB)
maintenance.para: Determine the APU Drive Generator System failure mode and accomplish the following steps as applicable:

numlitem.para: APU Drive Generator Bearing Failure:
Check the EICAS for status message APU GEN BEARING which indicates an APU generator bearing failure.
If a bearing failure has occurred, deactivate the associated generator as follows:
Verify BATTERY switch, located on P5 overhead panel, is set to ON.
Verify the associated APU generator FIELD OFF light is illuminated on the P461 panel.

note.para: If the FIELD OFF light is extinguished, momentarily toggle and release the associated APU generator field switch on the P461 panel.

numlitem.para: Place INOP placard on appropriate APU GEN switch (P5 panel).
Limit operation of the APU to ground use only (do not use during takeoff).
Do not operate the APU in excess of 15 hours total cumulative time following the initial bearing failure. Refer to item 49-11-1 to deactivate the APU if necessary.

note.para: The generator will be operating in a no-load condition when the APU is operating. Operation of APU for more than 15 hours total cumulative time following the initial generator bearing failure may result in severe damage to the APU generator and APU.

numlitem.para: APU Drive Generator Electrical Failure, Auxiliary Generator Control Unit (AGCU) Failure:
Verify EICAS status message APU GEN BEARING is not displayed.
If status message is present, refer to (M) step 1 “APU Drive Generator Bearing Failure.”
If the messages are not present, deactivate the generator(s) as follows:
Verify BATTERY switch, located on P5 overhead panel, is set to ON.
Verify the associated APU generator FIELD OFF light is illuminated on the P461 panel.

note.para: If the FIELD OFF light is extinguished, momentarily toggle and release the associated APU generator field switch on the P461 panel.

numlitem.para: Place INOP placard on appropriate APU GEN switch (P5 panel).

The generator will be operating in a no-load condition when the APU is operating. In this configuration, the potential for a generator bearing failure still exists. If the APU is operated, verify EICAS status message APU GEN BEARING is not displayed before each departure.
If status message is present, refer to step 1, “APU Driven Generator Bearing Failure.”
Auxiliary Power Breaker (APB) Failure:
Apply electrical power through external power receptacle No. 1 or apply power from engine-driven generator No.1 and/or No. 2.

note.para: If electrical power (from either an external power source or from engine-driven generator power) cannot be connected to the aircraft, this is an indication auxiliary power breaker No. 1 is failed closed.

numlitem.para: Verify all BUS TIE switches, located on P5 overhead panel, are set to AUTO.
Verify that the ISLN lights, located on P5 overhead panel, are extinguished.

note.para: If any ISLN lights are illuminated when engine generator power is applied, this is an indication auxiliary power breaker (No. 1 and No. 2) is failed closed.

numlitem.para: Verify split system breaker OPEN light, located on P461 pilots’ overhead maintenance panel is extinguished.

note.para: If split system breaker light is illuminated, toggle SPLIT SYSTEM BREAKER switch to close breaker. If split system breaker OPEN light remains illuminated, this is an indication auxiliary power breaker No. 2 is failed closed.

item.title: APU Drive Generator Systems (Generator, AGCU, APB) – Removed and APU is Deactivated

remarks.para: May be inoperative and removed provided APU is deactivated.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
APU GEN ___
When dispatching with APU Gen 1 inop turn #4 DEMAND PUMP to AUTO for pushback, #4 AUX inop due to Gnd Handling bus not powered.
If EEC CLNG SUP FAN status message is displayed, it can be cleared by rotating the EQUIP COOLING switch to OVRD, then back to NORM.

placard.para: Placard APU Selector Switch "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Open and collar the following P83 panel circuit breakers: AIR INLET DOOR, APU PRIMARY CONT, and APU START.
Open and collar the P6 main power supply panel circuit breaker APU ALTN CONT.
See AMM 09-11-00 for towing aircraft if APU not used.

remarks.para: One may be inoperative closed provided:

numlitem.para: No. 4 is operative, and
Approach minimums do not require its use.

note.para: If No. 1, 2, or 3 BTB is inoperative, triple channel autoland will not be available.
The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
EC BTB ___

numlitem.para: Downgrade Aircraft Category Dispatch Status to CAT 2.

placard.para: Placard Bus Tie Breaker (BTB) "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.title: BUS TIE BREAKERS (BTB)
maintenance.para: Deferral of this item requires downgrading to the status indicated in the A/C STATUS DISPATCH column below.
Use the following procedure to verify the bus tie breaker (BTB) failure condition:

numlitem.para: Apply APU or external power, if not already accomplished.
Verify all BUS TIE switches, located on P5 overhead panel, are set to AUTO and the ISLN lights are extinguished.

note.para: If any ISLN lights are illuminated with all BUS TIE switches set to the AUTO position and both sync buses powered, this is an indication of an open bus tie breaker.

remarks.para: May be inoperative closed provided No.1, 2, and 3 are operative.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
EC BTB 4

placard.para: Placard Bus Tie Breaker (BTB) "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.para: Use the following procedure to verify the bus tie breaker (BTB) failure condition:

numlitem.para: Apply APU or external power, if not already accomplished.
Verify all BUS TIE switches, located on P5 overhead panel, are set to AUTO and the ISLN lights are extinguished.

note.para: If any ISLN lights are illuminated with all BUS TIE switches set to the AUTO position and both sync buses powered, this is an indication of an open bus tie breaker.

remarks.para: May be inoperative closed provided all BTB’s are operative.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
SPLIT BREAKER

numlitem.para: If EEC CLNG SUP FAN status message is displayed, it can be cleared by rotating the EQUIP COOLING switch to OVRD, then back to NORM.

placard.para: Placard Split System Breaker (SSB) "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.para: No maintenance action is required if SSB is inoperative closed.

para.emphasis: If SSB is inoperative open, it must be replaced per AMM 24-22-02/401

Alternate procedure if SSB is inoperative open - replace SSB (P/N 60B 00010-30) with P/N 60B 00010-25 (APB, BTB, GCB contactor). Dispatch with the substitute -25 part is limited to 10 days (Category C) until permanent SSB repair is made.

maintenance.para: Use the following procedure to verify whether the split system breaker (SSB) has failed closed:

numlitem.para: Apply power from source 1 only (APU GEN 1 or EXT PWR 1), (AMM 24-22-00/201).
Verify all BUS TIE switches, located on P5 overhead panel, are set to AUTO.
Verify ON light on selected power source switch is illuminated.
Verify ISLN lights on all BUS TIE switches are extinguished, and the EICAS status message(s) ELEC BTB_ is not displayed.
Ensure that the selected power source is supplying both sides of this synchronous bus.
Verify that the following EICAS messages are not displayed:

If these messages are displayed, this indicates the SSB is open. To check if the SSB has failed open, press and release the guarded SSB switch located on the P461 Overhead Maintenance Panel and observe the SSB OPEN light. If it remains illuminated and the messages illustrated below remain displayed, the SSB has failed open and dispatch is not allowed.
Attempt to apply power from source 2 (APU GEN 2 or EXT PWR 2).
Verify that the selected power source ON light will not illuminate.
Verify that the SSB OPEN light is not illuminated and the advisory message ELEC SSB OPEN is not displayed.

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard APU Generator Power ON Light(s) "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard APU Generator Power AVAIL Light(s) "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: One indication may be inoperative provided associated BTB is verified to be operative.

placard.para: Placard AC BUS ISLN Light "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.para: Perform the following procedure to verify the bus ISLN lights failure condition indicated:

numlitem.para: Apply APU or external power, if not already accomplished.
Verify ON light on APU GEN or EXT PWR switches are illuminated.
Verify all BUS TIE switches, located on P5 overhead panel, are set to AUTO, and ISLN lights are extinguished.
Access CMC electrical maintenance page and verify that all AC busses are powered in normal voltage range.

item.title: Engine and APU Generator FIELD OFF Lights (Overhead Maintenance Panel)

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard appropriate FIELD OFF Light(s) "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Split System Breaker OPEN Light (Overhead Maintenance Panel)

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard Split Systems Breaker (SSB) OPEN Light "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard appropriate GEN CONT Light(s) "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ELEC TR UNIT ___

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "MAIN TRU INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided APU battery is selected for APU start.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ELEC TR UNIT ___

numlitem.para: With an inoperative APU TRU, select the APU battery on the APU Start Source Switch located on the overhead panel, prior to APU start.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "APU TRU INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: DC Bus Isolation Relays – No. 1, 2, or 3

remarks.para: One may be inoperative closed provided:

numlitem.para: No. 4 is operative, and
Approach minimums do not require its use.

note.para: If No. 1, 2, or 3 DC Isolation Relay is inoperative, triple channel autoland will not be available.

numlitem.para: Downgrade Aircraft Category Dispatch Status to CAT 2.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "MAIN (or APU) TRU INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.para: Deferral of this item requires downgrading to the status indicated in the A/C STATUS DISPATCH column below.

remarks.para: May be inoperative closed provided No. 1, 2, and 3 are operative.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "____ DC BUS ISOL RELAY INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: May be inoperative or removed.

note.para: Not installed on N580UP.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "TOWING INVERTER INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Set the TOWING POWER switch, located on the P461 Overhead Maintenance Panel, to OFF.
Open and collar circuit breaker C10388 TOWING/BAT POWER located on the P180 DC Power Distribution Panel.
If it is necessary to remove the Towing Inverter:
Disconnect the J1 connector on the M6036 static inverter.
Remove two screws and washers. Remove TB1 cover.
Remove nut, washer, and lock washer from each terminal.
Remove, insulate, and secure the positive and negative terminal wires from TB1.
Remove the towing static inverter from the E-30 equipment rack.

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

numlitem.para: Use APU for electrical power prior to engine start.
APU must be operative for electrical power.

placard.para: Placard appropriate EXT POWER SWITCH(s) "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

note.para: The repetitive inspection required when this item is inoperative must be documented in the Aircraft Logbook at the prescribed intervals. (Refer to GMM, Chapter 3, Section 6.)

numlitem.para: Secure External Power Receptacle door closed using speed tape.
Clean area with solvent to provide suitable bonding surface.
Use a minimum of 2 inch overlap of External Power Receptacle door opening.
Place additional INOP placard on speed tape.
Reinspect speed tape security/condition once each flight day.

item.chgdesc: Revises Maintenance procedure.
item.title: Electrical Load Control Units (ELCU) – Utility Power ELCU's

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Dispatch limitations for affected utility bus equipment are observed, and
For Passenger/Combi, utility bus #4 ELCU is operative.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ELEC UTIL BUS ___

numlitem.para: Observe dispatch limitations for affected utility bus equipment.
For Utility Bus #1, the following equipment is affected:
–Fuel Boost Pump Main Forward #3
–Equipment Cooling Supply Fan Power
–Left Forward Cargo Heater Power
–Vent Fan Power Lower Forward Power
–Captain Aux Heater
–F/O Aux Heater
For Utility Bus #2, the following equipment is affected:
–Override Jettison Pumps Forward 2 and 3
–Left Center Override Jettison Pump
–Captain Power Seat
–Lav Lights
–Water and Waste Water Line Heaters
For Utility Bus #3, the following equipment is affected:
–Lights on the Main Cargo Deck
–Fuel Boost Pump Main Forward #2
–F/O Power Seat
–Right Forward Cargo Heater Power
–Vent Fans for Bulk Cargo and Lower Aft Cargo
–R CDU
–Lav Water Heater
For Utility Bus #4, the following equipment is affected:
–ACM Mass Flow Indication
–Flight Deck Fan
–Upper Deck Lav Flush Motor
If the ELCU is inoperative for the #1 utility bus, observe the following limitations:
Center wing tank fuel must be included as part of the ZFW but is considered usable.
Main tanks 1, 2, 3 and 4 must contain a minimum of 8610 lbs of fuel for landing.
Remaining main tank boost pumps, main tank fuel quantity indicating systems and remaining crossfeed valves are operative.
Carriage of animals or perishables in the lower forward cargo compartment is prohibited.
If the ELCU is inoperative for the #2 utility bus, observe the following limitations:
Aft jettison pumps in tank 2 and 3 must be operative.
All engine driven generator systems are operative.
All main tanks 2 and 3 boost pumps are operative.
If right center tank override jettison is operative, wing tank fuel must be adequate to reach a suitable airport if the remaining pump fails and center tank fuel must be included as part of the ZFW.
If right center tank override jettison is inoperative, center tank fuel is included as part of the ZFW and is considered unusable.
If the ELCU is inoperative for the #3 utility bus, observe the following limitations:
Center wing tank fuel must be included as part of the ZFW but is considered usable.
Main tanks 1, 2, 3 and 4 must contain a minimum of 8610 lbs of fuel for landing.
Remaining main tank boost pumps, main tank fuel quantity indicating systems and remaining crossfeed valves are operative.
There are no limitations for #4 ELCU inoperative.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel:
"______ UTILITY BUS ELCU INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

para.revision: Aircraft must be dispatched using the appropriate MELs for items listen on the inoperative utility bus.

entry.para: FUEL OVRD JTSN PUMP CTR L
VENT FAN PWR-1 LWR FWD CAR
VEN FAN PWR-1 LWR FWD CAR
THSKD LT CARGO DR MN DK
CLG LT MN DK AFT R
SWL LT MN DK AFT R
SWL LT MN DK AFT L
SWL LT MN DK FWD L
SWL LT MN DK CTR R
SWL LT MN DK CTR L
VENT FAN PWR LWR AFT CAR

note.para: Advisory messages ELEC UTIL BUS L and/or ELEC UTIL BUS R will remain displayed.

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard appropriate UTILITY POWER OFF LIGHT(s) "INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Flight Crew Seats Power Adjustment System

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard "______ SEAT POWER ADJUST INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Flight Crew Seats Manual Adjustment System – Recline Systems

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Affected seat is secured in an upright position,
Seat is acceptable to affected crewmember, and
Repairs are made within two flight days.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "______ SEAT RECLINE INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Ensure inoperable recline system is secured in an upright position acceptable to crewmember.

item.title: Flight Crew Seats Manual Adjustment System – Armrests

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Affected armrest is stowed in the retracted position or removed, and
Seat is acceptable to affected crewmember.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "______ SEAT ARMREST INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Ensure inoperable armrest(s) is stowed either in the retracted position or is removed.

item.title: Flight Crew Seats Manual Adjustment System – Lumbar/ Thigh Supports

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided seat is acceptable to the affected crewmember.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "______ SEAT ______ MODE INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Flight Crew Seats Manual Adjustment System – Headrests

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided seat is acceptable to the affected crewmember.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "______ SEAT HEADREST INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: FLIGHT CREW SEATS MANUAL ADJUSTMENT SYSTEM – VERTICAL ADJUSTMENT

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Seat is acceptable to the affected crewmember, and
Repairs are made within two flight days.

placard.para: Placard below Captains PFD on P-1-1 panel: " ____SEAT VERTCAL ADJ INOP". Enter Item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Verify affected seat locks in a vertical position.

item.title: Observer Seat(s) Primary Observer Seat (Including Associated Equipment) – Passenger Seat Available

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: A passenger seat in the passenger cabin is available to the FAA inspector for the performance of official duties, and
Repairs are made within two flight days.

placard.para: Placard adjacent to Primary Observer audio panel: "PRIMARY OBSERVER SEAT INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.chgdesc: Adds Notes to proviso per MMEL.
item.title: Observer Seat(s) Primary Observer Seat (Including Associated Equipment) – Second Observer’s Seat Available

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Secondary observer’s seat is available to the FAA inspector for the performance of official duties, and
Repairs are made within two flight days.

para.revision: This proviso is intended to provide for occupancy of the above seat by an FAA inspector when the minimum safety equipment (safety belt and oxygen) is functional and the inspector determines the conditions to be acceptable.
The pilot in command will determine if the minimum safety equipment is functional for other persons authorized to occupy the observer's seat(s).

placard.para: Placard adjacent to Primary Observer audio panel: "PRIMARY OBSERVER SEAT INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.chgdesc: Revises Note in proviso per MMEL.
item.title: Observer Seat(s) Primary Observer Seat (Including Associated Equipment) – Seat Usable

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Required minimum safety equipment (safety belt and oxygen) is available,
Seat is acceptable to the FAA inspector for the performance of official duties, and
Repairs are made within two flight days.

para.revision: This proviso is intended to provide for occupancy of the above seat by an FAA inspector when the minimum safety equipment (safety belt and oxygen) is functional and the inspector determines the conditions to be acceptable.

note.para: The pilot-in-command will determine if the minimum safety equipment is functional for other persons authorized to occupy any observers seat(s).

placard.para: Placard adjacent to Primary Observer audio panel: "PRIMARY OBSERVER SEAT INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Observer Seat(s) Additional Observer’s Seat (Including Associated Equipment)

note.para: The pilot-in-command will determine if the minimum safety equipment is functional for other persons authorized to occupy any observer’s seat(s).

placard.para: Placard adjacent to Additional Observer audio panel: "ADDITIONAL OBSERVER SEAT INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: May be inoperative, damaged or missing provided that the item(s) is deferred in accordance with the operator’s NEF deferral program. The NEF program, procedures and processes are outlined in the UPS General Maintenance Manual (GMM). (M) and (O) procedures, if required, must be available to the flight crew and included in the operator’s appropriate document.

note.para: Exterior lavatory door ash trays are not considered NEF items.

numlitem.para: Contact Aircraft Maintenance for deferral.

placard.para: Placard as applicable per AMC instructions.

numlitem.para: Contact Aircraft Maintenance Control (AMC).

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Seat does not block an Emergency Exit,
Seat does not restrict any passenger from access to the main aircraft aisle, and
The affected seat(s) is blocked and placarded DO NOT OCCUPY.

note.para: A seat with an inoperative seat belt is considered inoperative.
Inoperative seats do not affect the required number of Flight Attendants.
Affected seat(s) may include the seat(s) behind and/or adjacent outboard seats.
Upper Deck Occupancy may be restricted.
Inoperative seat must not restrict any supernumerary from access to the aircraft aisle.

placard.para: Placard affected seat: "SEAT INOP – DO NOT OCCUPY". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Secure seat back in the upright position if possible and block off seat such that it can not be occupied.
If discrepant seat is along the aisle then both seats in that row will need placarded per MEL and can not be occupied.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Seat does not block an Emergency Exit,
Seat does not restrict any passenger from access to the main aircraft aisle, and
The affected seat(s) is blocked and placarded DO NOT OCCUPY.

note.para: A seat with an inoperative seat belt is considered inoperative.
Inoperative seats do not affect the required number of Flight Attendants.
Affected seat(s) may include the seat(s) behind and/or adjacent outboard seats.
Upper Deck Occupancy may be restricted.
Inoperative seat must not restrict any supernumerary from access to the aircraft aisle.

placard.para: Placard affected seat: "SEAT INOP – DO NOT OCCUPY". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Secure seat back in upright position if possible and block off seat such that it can not be occupied.
If discrepant seat is along the aisle then both seats in that row will need placarded per MEL and can not be occupied.

If the affected seat is in the forward row against the sidewall and the seatback can not be stowed, then both the affected seat and the seat behind will need to be placarded per MEL and can not be occupied.
If discrepant seat is in the forward row along the aisle then all seats in both rows will need to be placarded per MEL and can not be occupied.

item.chgdesc: Adds the word "back" in proviso per MMEL.
item.title: Passenger Seats – Recline Mechanism

para.revision: May be inoperative and seat occupied provided seat back is secured in the full upright position.

placard.para: Placard affected seat: "SEAT RECLINE MECHANISM INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Secure affected seat in full upright position.

item.title: Passenger Seats – Under Seat Baggage Restraining Bars

remarks.para: May be inoperative or missing provided:

numlitem.para: Baggage is not stowed under seat with inoperative restraining bar,
Associated seat is placarded DO NOT STOW BAGGAGE UNDER THIS SEAT, and
Procedures are established to alert Cabin Crew of inoperative restraining bar.
Crew should ensure that there is no baggage stowed under seat with inoperative restraining bar.

placard.para: Placard affected seat: "DO NOT STOW BAGGAGE UNDER THIS SEAT". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.chgdesc: Adds the word "back" in proviso per MMEL.
item.title: Passenger Seats – Armrests WITH RECLINE MECHANISM

remarks.para: May be inoperative or missing and seat occupied provided:

numlitem.para: Armrest does not block any Emergency Exit,
Armrest does not restrict any passenger from access to the main aircraft aisle, and

para.revision: If armrest is missing, seat back is secured in the full upright position.

placard.para: Placard affected seat: "SEAT ARMREST INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Secure armrest(s) in retracted position or remove affected armrest.

item.title: PASSENGER SEATS – ARMREST WITHOUT RECLINE MECHANISM

remarks.para: May be inoperative or missing and seat occupied provided:

numlitem.para: Armrest does not block an Emergency Exit, and
Armrest does not restrict any passenger from access to the main aircraft aisle.

placard.para: Placard affected seat: "SEAT ARMREST INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Overhead Storage Bin(s)/Cabin and Galley Storage Compartments/ Closets – DOOR SECURED

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Procedures are established to secure compartment CLOSED,
Any emergency equipment located in affected compartment is considered inoperative,
Affected compartment is not used for storage of any item(s) except for those permanently affixed, and
Associated bin or compartment is prominently placaded: “DO NOT USE”.

note.para: If no partitions are installed, the entire overhead storage compartment is considered one bin or compartment.

placard.para: Placard associated bin, compartment, "DO NOT USE" so as to prevent its use. Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item log.

numlitem.para: Ensure every affected bin is empty (except for permanently affixed items) and secured closed after crew inspection.

item.title: OVERHEAD STORAGE BIN(S)/CABIN AND GALLEY STORAGE COMPARTMENTS/CLOSETS – DOOR REMOVED

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Affected door(s) is removed,
Associated bin or compartment is not used for storage of any items, except those permanently affixed,
Associated bin or compartment is prominently placarded: “DO NOT USE”,
Procedures are established and used to alert crew members and passengers of inoperative bins or compartment, and
Passengers are briefed that associated bin or compartment is not used.

note.para: If no partitions are installed, the entire overhead storage compartment is considered one bin or compartment.
Any emergency equipment located in the associated compartment (permanently affixed) is available for use.

numlitem.para: Brief supernumeraries not to use inoperative storage bin/compartment.

placard.para: Placard associated bin, compartment, "DO NOT USE" so as to prevent its use. Enter Item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Ensure affected bins, compartments and closets are empty (except for permanently affixed items).
Remove affected door(s).

item.title: Overhead Storage Bin(s)/Cabin and Galley Storage Compartments/Closets – Multi Latch/Quarter Turn Lug Installations

remarks.para: One latch/lug per component may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Remaining latch(es)/lug(s) on affected compartments are operative, and
If affected compartment is used for a galley cart, the cart remains empty.
Effected compartment must remain empty.

placard.para: Install Placard next to Discrepant latch: "LATCH INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Secure inop bins/compartments closed.

item.title: Overhead Storage Bin(s)/Cabin and Galley Storage Compartments/Closets – Storage Compartment Key Locks

remarks.para: May be inoperative in the unlocked position provided doors can be secured by other means.

placard.para: Install Placard next to Discrepant latch: "LOCK INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Secure inop bins/compartments closed.

item.chgdesc: Adds the word "cabin" to title and proviso per MMEL.

title.revision: Galley/Cabin Waste Receptacle Access Doors/Covers

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Associated waste container is empty,
Receptacle access is secured to prevent waste introduction into the receptacle, and

para.revision: Procedures are established to ensure that sufficient galley/cabin waste receptacles are available to accommodate all waste that may be generated on a flight.

numlitem.para: Prior to blockout ensure an adequate number of garbage bags are onboard.

placard.para: Placard adjacent to the waste access door "DO NO USE" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Ensure waste receptacle is empty.
Block access door with tape.

item.title: EXTERIOR LAVATORY DOOR ASHTRAYS – AIRCRAFT WITH ONLY ONE EXTERIOR LAVATORY DOOR ASHTRAY INSTALLED

remarks.para: May be missing provided it is replaced within 3 calendar days.

placard.para: Placard "LAV DR ASHTRAY MISSING" on Lavatory Door next to where the ashtray mounts. Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Lavatory Waste Receptacle Access Doors/ Covers

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Associated waste container is empty,
Receptacle access is secured to prevent waste introduction into the receptacle,
Lavatory is used only by crewmembers, and
Associated lavatory entrance door is locked closed and placarded, INOPERATIVE – DO NOT ENTER.

note.para: These provisions are not intended to prohibit lavatory use or inspections by crewmembers.

placard.para: Placard adjacent to the waste access door "DO NOT USE" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Ensure waste receptacle is empty.
Block access door with tape.

remarks.para: May be damaged or missing provided procedures are established and used to verify the associated cargo compartment remains empty or contains only empty cargo handling equipment, ballast (ballast may be loaded in ULDs), or Fly Away Kits.

note.para: UPS does not carry Fly Away Kits in voided cargo compartments.

numlitem.para: &Ensuretheloadsupervisor;
Associated lower cargo compartment is empty or contains only empty cargo handling equipment.

placard.para: Placard below captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "______ PANELS DAMAGED/MISSING IN ______ LOWER COMPARTMENT". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: NOTE: Any portion of system(s) that is operative may be used.

placard.para: Placard below captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "CARGO HANDLING SYSTEM _______ INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

note.para: Ensure any removed cargo handling system components, which are not replaced with serviceable cargo handling system components, are placed in the PFM box, not removed from the aircraft.

numlitem.para: Positions 1 thru 7, 17L, 17R, 18L, 18R, 19L1, 19L2, 19R1, 19R2, 23R and 24 are allowed to be inoperative and remain installed on the aircraft. (see note below)
Positions near the side cargo door are critical to loading operation and should remain in serviceable condition by swapping with other positions if possible. (see note below)

note.para: All Steerable Retractable PDU's can be swapped to/from any position.
It is recommended that the PDU's be swapped from the following positions in the order listed to minimize impact to the loading and unloading operation: 24, 1, 2, 3, 5L and 5R.
Each PDU has a two foot harness that is to be kept with the PDU. The harness should be disconnected at aircraft connector stanchion under the floor and moved with the PDU.

numlitem.para: Swapping PDU's:
Determine which operative PDU can be swapped.
Remove selected operative PDU (with harness) and move to inoperative PDU position.
Manually retract inoperative PDU by depressing red button on the face of the PDU while applying a downward force (weight) on wheel.
Remove inoperative PDU.
Prepare to install operative PDU by securing electrical plugs to connectors below floor.
Install PDU and secure unit to tray.

Before installing inoperative PDU in the swapped position, remove the three dust caps from the park position connector receptacles (frequently called “dummy receptacles” located below main deck floor on the support structure) and place caps on the three aircraft side connector receptacles normally used for the PDU harness connection.
Connect the inoperative PDU harness plugs to the aircraft park position connector receptacles.
Install PDU and secure unit to tray.
Verify swapped operative PDU shows in service (green box) on Cargo Maintenance Computer.
Verify swapped inoperative PDU shows out of service (black box) on Cargo Maintenance Computer.
PDU left inoperative in position:

Manually retract inoperative PDU by depressing red button on the face of the PDU while applying a downward force (weight) on wheel. If a container is on top of the PDU and the red button can not be accessed then use one of the following methods. Use the Cargo Maintenance Control Panel to select the applicable PDU and retract command or access the underside of the PDU and pull the release ring.
Gain access to PDU harness connectors by either removing PDU or accessing the PDU from underneath.
Deactivate the PDU electrically by removing the three harness connectors from receptacles (located below main deck floor on the support structure.)

Remove the three dust caps from the park position connector receptacles (frequently called “dummy receptacles”) and place them on the three aircraft side connector receptacles used for the PDU harness connection.
Connect the inoperative PDU harness plugs to the aircraft park position connector receptacles.
If PDU was removed for harness access - reinstall PDU and secure.
If PDU was accessed from underneath – reinstall removed panels.
Verify inoperative PDU shows out of service (black box) on Cargo Maintenance Computer.

note.para: Cluster terminology is referencing electrical actuation only. Actual Tray Mounted PDU's are individually installed in trays.

numlitem.para: One Tray Mounted PDU can be inoperative in each pallet position cluster.
Lower Deck Tray Mounted PDU can be inoperative, damaged or missing in each pallet position.

note.para: Inoperative lower deck tray mounted PDU drive rollers are below the lower cargo deck. The drive rollers operative or inoperative do not provide any braking assistance. For these reasons, inoperative lower deck tray mounted PDU's can remain installed on the aircraft until a serviceable unit is available to be installed.

numlitem.para: Ball mat mounted PDU's can be inoperative, damaged or missing.

note.para: Inoperative lower deck ball mat mounted PDU drive rollers are below the ball mat. The drive rollers operative or inoperative do not provide any braking assistance. For these reasons, inoperative lower deck ball mat mounted PDU's can remain installed on the aircraft until a serviceable unit is available to be installed.

para.emphasis: Tray Mounted Rollers (Lower and Main Deck):

numlitem.para: No two adjacent rollers may be damaged or missing.
Ball transfer units on either side of missing or damaged roller must be operative.
Damaged rollers are allowed to be removed provided steps 1 and 2 are complied with.
Each cargo position must be equipped with a minimum of one serviceable brake roller.
Brake rollers are allowed to be damaged or missing provided the requirements in step 1 are fulfilled.
Joystick ball and/or rubber base boot may be missing or damaged.

note.para: Inoperative lower deck cargo control panel will require the lower deck to be loaded manually.

numlitem.para: Continued operation with damaged ball transfer units (BTU) is not permitted in the following locations: (See Figure 1)
Any BTU adjacent to a PDU pan, whether the PDU is fitted or not.
Any BTU adjacent to a transversal or longitudinal guide.
Any BTU adjacent to the edge of the ball mat.
More than two neighboring damaged BTUs.
Damaged balls that meet the above criteria are allowed to be removed.

caution.para: DAMAGED BTU'S OR BTU FLANGES ARE ONLY PERMITTED IN THIS AREA (GREY MARKED) MAXIMUM 2 ADJACENT BTU'S.

para.emphasis: Ball Transfer Unit (Dual Ball Assy) Balls (Lower and Main Deck):

numlitem.para: Ball transfer units (dual ball) may be damaged or missing.
No two adjacent ball transfer (dual ball) units may be damaged or missing.
Damaged ball transfer units (dual ball) are allowed to be removed provided serviceable adjacent ball mats are installed on the aircraft.

para.emphasis: Ball Transfer Unit (Single Ball Assy) Balls (Lower and Main Deck):

numlitem.para: Ball transfer units (single ball) may be damaged or missing.
Rollers or ball transfer units inboard and outboard of missing or damaged ball transfer units need to be operative.
Damaged ball transfer units (single ball) are allowed to be removed provided steps 1 and 2 above are complied with.

para.emphasis: Center Guide Ball Transfer Units (Main Deck):

numlitem.para: Ball transfer units can be damaged or missing. Remove damaged ball transfer units as necessary.
Can be damaged or missing. Remove damaged Anti Roll Out Stop/Bumper as necessary.

para.emphasis: Nose, Side and Park Guide Rails (Lower or Main Deck):

numlitem.para: Only cosmetic damage is allowed.

note.para: Rails damage allowances (loading considerations) are covered under Cargo Restraint Systems in MEL 25-54-1-1/-2.

numlitem.para: Can be damaged or inoperative.
Select button lights can be inoperative.

note.para: This computer is used as a diagnostic/troubleshooting tool. The system will function normally regardless of the condition of the cargo maintenance computer.

para.emphasis: Remote Cargo Control Panel (RCCP) (Main Deck Opposite of Side Door):

numlitem.para: Joystick ball and/or rubber base boot may be missing or damaged.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.
Panel may be damaged or inoperative.
Can be damaged or inoperative.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.

note.para: Possible loading problems with long pallets may exist when one or more of the 20FT remote panels are inoperative.

If a local cargo control panel becomes inoperative, the local control panel fwd or aft of the inoperative panel(s) can be used to control the PDUs associated with the inoperative local cargo control panels.

numlitem.para: Joystick ball and/or rubber base boot may be missing or damaged.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.

para.emphasis: Master Cargo Control Panel (MCCP) (Main Deck by Crew Entry Door):

numlitem.para: Joystick ball and/or rubber base boot may be missing or damaged.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.

note.para: The Main Deck Cargo Handling System will not function without a serviceable Master Cargo Control Panel. Loading from either the nose or side main cargo doors will have to be accomplished manually.

para.emphasis: Auxiliary Cargo Control Panel (ACCP) (Main Deck – Nose Area):

numlitem.para: Joystick ball and/or rubber base boot may be missing or damaged.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.
Panel may be damaged or inoperative.

note.para: If the auxiliary control panel were to become inoperative, the ULDs to be loaded in positions 1, 2 and 3 will have to be positioned by hand.

para.emphasis: Side Door Master Cargo Control Panel (SDMCCP) (Main Deck):

numlitem.para: Joystick ball and/or rubber base boot may be missing or damaged.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.

note.para: An inoperative side door master cargo control panel will require cargo loading through the main deck side cargo door to be accomplished manually.

numlitem.para: Can be damaged or inoperative.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.

note.para: Any portion of system(s) that is operative may be used.

placard.para: Placard below captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "CARGO HANDLING SYSTEM _______ INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

note.para: Ensure any removed cargo handling system components, which are not replaced with serviceable cargo handling system components, are placed in the PFM box, not removed from the aircraft.

numlitem.para: Floor mounted PDU are allowed to be inoperative and remain installed on the aircraft.
Positions near the side cargo door are critical to loading operation and should remain in serviceable condition by swapping with other positions if possible. (see note below)

note.para: 90° Steerable/Retractable PDU's are installed in positions 17L (R), 18L (R), 19L1 (R1), and 19L2 (R2). These may be swapped to/from these positions.

Steerable/Non-Retractable PDU's are installed in positions 2, 3, 4L thru 7L, 4R thru 7R, 23R, and 24. A Steerable/Non-Retractable PDU may be swapped to/from another Steerable/Non-Retractable PDU position.
Fixed/Non-Retractable PDU's are installed in positions 8L thru 16L, 8R thru 16R, 20L thru 23L, 20R thru 22R and 24.
Each PDU has a two foot harness that is to be kept with the PDU. The harness should be disconnected at aircraft connector stanchion under the floor and moved with the PDU.

numlitem.para: Swapping 90° Steerable/Retractable PDU's:
Determine which operative PDU can be swapped.
Remove selected operative PDU (with harness) and move to inoperative PDU position.
Remove inoperative PDU.
Prepare to install operative PDU by securing electrical plugs to connectors below floor.
Install PDU and secure unit to tray.
Manually retract inoperative PDU by using a 3/8” ratchet extension on the underside of the rotary steering actuator and turn counterclockwise until PDU is fully retracted.

Before installing inoperative PDU in the swapped position, remove the three dust caps from the park position connector receptacles (frequently called “dummy receptacles” located below main deck floor on the support structure) and place caps on the three aircraft side connector receptacles normally used for the PDU harness connection.
Connect the inoperative PDU harness plugs to the aircraft park position connector receptacles.
Install PDU and secure unit to tray.
If PDU was accessed from underneath – reinstall removed panels.
Verify swapped operative PDU can be electrically operated from the master cargo control panel (M1).
Swapping Steerable/Non-Retractable or Fixed/Non-Retractable PDU's:
Determine which operative PDU can be swapped.
Remove selected operative PDU (with harness) and move to inoperative PDU position.
Remove inoperative PDU.
Prepare to install operative PDU by securing electrical plugs to connectors below floor.
Install PDU and secure unit to tray.

Before installing inoperative PDU in the swapped position, remove the dust cap from the park position connector receptacles (frequently called “dummy receptacles” located below main deck oor on the support structure) and place cap on the aircraft side connector receptacle normally used for the PDU harness connection.
Connect the inoperative PDU harness plug to the aircraft park position connector receptacle.
Install PDU and secure unit to tray.
If PDU was accessed from underneath – reinstall removed panels.
Verify swapped operative PDU can be electrically operated from the master cargo control panel (M1).
90º Steerable/retractable PDU left inoperable in position:
Gain access to PDU harness connectors by either removing PDU or accessing the PDU from underneath.
Deactivate the PDU electrically by removing the three harness connectors from receptacles (located below main deck oor on the support structure.)
Manually retract inoperative PDU by using a 3/8” ratchet extension on the underside of the rotary steering actuator and turn counterclockwise until PDU is fully retracted.

Remove the three dust caps from the park position connector receptacles (frequently called “dummy receptacles”) and place them on the three aircraft side connector receptacles used for the PDU harness connection.
Connect the inoperative PDU harness plugs to the aircraft park position connector receptacles.
If PDU was removed for harness access - reinstall PDU and secure.
If PDU was accessed from underneath - reinstall removed panels.
Verify inoperative PDU shows out of service (black box) on Cargo Maintenance Computer.
PDU Drive Wheel Manual Disengage (Steerable/Non-retractable or Fixed/Non-Retractable PDU):
PDU’S WITH MANUAL DISENGAGE LEVER IN THE MAIN DECK CARGO AREA:
Lift the disengage lever to the fully up position to disengage the drive wheel from the drive wheel actuator.
Make sure that the drive wheel can turn freely in the forward and aft direction.
PDU’S WITHOUT DISENGAGE LEVER IN THE MAIN DECK CARGO AREA:
Remove the ceiling lining as required beneath the PDU to be disengaged.
Open drain pan door beneath PDU in lower cargo compartment ceiling.
Pull the handle and turn it counterclockwise (45 degrees) until it locks.
Make sure that the drive wheel can turn freely in the forward and aft directions.
Close drain pan door and install ceiling lining as required.
Lower Deck Tray Mounted PDU can be inoperative, damaged or missing in each pallet position.

note.para: Inoperative lower deck tray mounted PDU drive rollers are below the lower cargo deck. The drive rollers operative or inoperative do not provide any braking assistance. For these reasons, inoperative lower deck tray mounted PDU’s can remain installed on the aircraft until a serviceable unit is available to be installed.

numlitem.para: Ball mat mounted PDU’s can be inoperative, damaged or missing.

note.para: Inoperative lower deck ball mat mounted PDU drive rollers are below the ball mat. The drive rollers operative or inoperative do not provide any braking assistance. For these reasons, inoperative lower deck ball mat mounted PDU’s can remain installed on the aircraft until a serviceable unit is available to be installed.

para.emphasis: Tray Mounted Rollers (Lower and Main Deck):

numlitem.para: No two adjacent rollers may be damaged or missing.
Damaged rollers are allowed to be removed provided criteria in step 1 are complied with.
Only cosmetic damage is allowed to the tray itself.
Each cargo position must be equipped with a minimum of one serviceable brake roller.
Brake rollers are allowed to be damaged or missing provided the requirements in step 1 are fulfilled.
No two adjacent casters may be damaged or missing.
Damaged casters are allowed to be removed provided criteria in step 1 are complied with.
Only Cosmetic Damage is allowed to the tray.
Continued operation with damaged casters is not permitted in the following locations:
Any caster adjacent to a PDU pan, whether the PDU is fitted or not.
Any caster adjacent to a transversal or longitudinal guide.
Any caster adjacent to the edge of the ball mat.
More than two neighboring damaged casters.
Damaged casters are allowed to be removed provided criteria in step 1 are complied with.
Continued operation with damaged ball transfer units (BTU) is not permitted in the following locations:
Any caster adjacent to a PDU pan, whether the PDU is fitted or not.
Any caster adjacent to a transversal or longitudinal guide.
Any caster adjacent to the edge of the ball mat.
More than two neighboring damaged casters.
Damaged casters are allowed to be removed provided criteria in step 1 are complied with.
Center guide rollers/casters may be damaged or missing.
No two adjacent center guides may have damaged or missing rollers/casters.
Only Cosmetic Damage is allowed to the tray.
Can be damaged or missing. Remove damaged Anti Roll Out Stop/Bumper as necessary.

para.emphasis: Nose, Side and Park Guide Rails (Lower or Main Deck):

numlitem.para: Only cosmetic damage is allowed.

note.para: Rails damage allowances (loading considerations) are covered under Cargo Restraint Systems in MEL 25-54-1-1 and 25-54-1-2.

para.emphasis: Remote Cargo Control Panel (RCCP) (Main Deck Opposite of Side Door):

numlitem.para: Joystick ball and/or rubber base boot may be missing or damaged.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.
Panel may be damaged or inoperative.
Can be damaged or inoperative.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.

note.para: Possible loading problems with long pallets may exist when one or more of the 20FT remote panels are inoperative.

If a local cargo control panel becomes inoperative, the local control panel fwd or aft of the inoperative panel(s) can be used to control the PDUs associated with the inoperative local cargo control panels.

numlitem.para: Joystick ball and/or rubber base boot may be missing or damaged.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.

para.emphasis: Master Cargo Control Panel (MCCP) (Main Deck by Crew Entry Door):

numlitem.para: Joystick ball and/or rubber base boot may be missing or damaged.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.

note.para: The Main Deck Cargo Handling System will not function without a serviceable Master Cargo Control Panel. Loading from either the nose or side main cargo doors will have to be accomplished manually.

para.emphasis: Auxiliary Cargo Control Panel (ACCP) (Main Deck – Nose Area):

numlitem.para: Joystick ball and/or rubber base boot may be missing or damaged.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.
Panel may be damaged or inoperative.

note.para: If the auxiliary control panel were to become inoperative, the ULDs to be loaded in positions 1, 2 and 3 will have to be positioned by hand.

para.emphasis: Side Door Master Cargo Control Panel (SDMCCP) (Main Deck):

numlitem.para: Joystick ball and/or rubber base boot may be missing or damaged.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.

note.para: An inoperative side door master cargo control panel will require cargo loading through the main deck side cargo door to be accomplished manually.

numlitem.para: Can be damaged or inoperative.
Cosmetic damage is allowed.
Select button lights can be inoperative.

item.title: CARGO RESTRAINT SYSTEMS – AIRCRAFT N570UP-N577UP

para.revision: May be inoperative or missing provided:
Acceptable cargo loading limits from an approved source, i.e., an Approved Cargo Loading Manual, or Weight and Balance Document are observed, and
Repairs are made prior to the completion of the next heavy maintenance visit.

numlitem.para: &Ensuretheloadsupervisor;

placard.para: Placard affected component and/or system inoperative. If position is weight limited, placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "______ CRGO POS WT LTD". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.title: CARGO RESTRAINT SYSTEMS (MAIN DECK) – 747-400F: N570UP-N577UP
maintenance.para: This section describes operational and weight restrictions for missing or inoperable restraints in the main deck cargo compartment.
Missing/Inoperative Restraints

note.para: Maximum loads for unit load devices assume all equipment is installed and operable. When equipment is missing or inoperable, allowable loading may be reduced. Certain instances of missing or inoperable equipment reduce the allowable loading to zero.

caution.para: CARE MUST BE EXERCISED DURING LOADING AND UNLOADING OF UNIT LOAD DEVICES WHEN EQUIPMENT IS MISSING/INOPERATIVE TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO AIRCRAFT STRUCTURE. IT IS ADVISABLE THAT MALFUNCTIONING EQUIPMENT BE REPAIRED OR REPLACED TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO OPERATIVE EQUIPMENT.

numlitem.para: The following equipment malfunctions do not constitute a load limit restriction:
Jammed or missing sill rollers.
Splitter rail malfunction.
Casters.

Restraint systems fall into four categories: side restraints, side/vertical restraints, forward/aft restraints and forward/aft/vertical restraints. Each restraint direction is considered separately when missing/inoperative restraint equipment exists (i.e. forward, aft, side left, side right and vertical loading). When a missing or inoperative restraint condition exists, the allowable weight is determined by considering each restraint direction separately and using the most limiting resultant allowable weight.
A lock is considered to be fully effective at the corner of a ULD if the centerline of the lockhead (pawl) lines up with the tangent of the ULD corner radius.
The following guidelines must be followed to determine allowable loads in a pallet position when missing or inoperable restraints are identified.
Determine the number of restraints available in each direction for each affected pallet position.
The ULD must be restrained vertically along all four sides.
A missing/inoperative side guide rail will cause the allowable weight for the affected position to be zero.

Missing/inoperative restraints in the same direction cannot be adjacent (i.e. two adjacent side restraints or two adjacent vertical restraints may not be missing or inoperative). Also, two restraints adjacent to a common corner cannot be missing/inoperable. If this condition exists, the allowable weight of the associated pallet position is 0 lb. (0 kg) except as noted in the following bullet.

An empty ULD can be carried in any position provided at least one restraint is operative in each (forward, aft, left and right) direction. In addition, one vertical restraint on each edge (forward, aft, left and right) must be operative.

para.emphasis: MAIN DECK - CARGO COMPARTMENT RESTRAINT SYSTEM – 747-400F: N570UP-N577UP

maintenance.para: The illustrations below identify the locations of the stops/locks/guides and the associated pallet positions for size codes A & M. Refer to the UPS 747-400F Weight and Balance Control and Loading Manual for other size codes.
The locations below show the pallet positions for the delivery configuration. The pallet locks have the same capability as the end stops.

note.para: Missing or inoperative center fitting pawls used for restraining M size ULD’S only do not have any affect on load limits of A size ULD’s.
Damage limited to one restraint pawl on a fitting does not affect the load carrying capability of adjacent restraint pawls on the same fitting.
Missing or inoperative center fitting pawls used for restraining A size containers do not have any affect on load limits of M size ULD’s.
Damage limited to one restraint pawl on a fitting does not affect the load carrying capability of adjacent restraint pawls on the same fitting.

(0 kg) except as noted in the following bullet.

para.emphasis: CARGO RESTRAINT SYSTEM - SIZE CODES A, M & N DOUBLE LOCKS – 747-400F: N570UP-N577UP

maintenance.para: The illustrations below identify the locations of the stops/locks/guides and the associated pallet positions for size codes A, M & N double locks.
The locations below show the positions for the delivery configuration.

note.para: CRAF SIDE RESTRAINT FITTINGS Commercial configuration – No restrictions. CRAF Configuration – refer to CRAF manual for loading limitations based on inoperative lock location(s).
CRAF location numbering is same position with "C" added (i.e. P1C)

entry.para: The following table shows the maximum allowable weights with missing or inoperative restraints:

para.emphasis: MAXIMUM ALLOWABLE LOADS (Lb.) WITH MISSING/INOPERATIVE RESTRAINTS

maintenance.para: [a] Size code A, M and N ULDs are restrained on the outboard sides by a continuous rail system with structural points labeled as black dots on page 1 of this section. This rail exists throughout the hold except in the doorsill area. All portions of this rail system must be operable or the following limitations apply:

numlitem.para: Do not load a ULD within 20 IN. of the inoperable/missing component.
Do not load cargo (transit) over the location with a missing/inoperative restraint.

maintenance.para: [b] Centerline Side/Vertical restraints are not required for A or M size ULD’s. Weight restrictions for missing or inoperable centerline restraints are only applicable for N size units.

maintenance.para: This section describes operational and weight restrictions for missing or inoperable restraints in the aft cargo compartment.
Missing/Inoperative Restraints

note.para: Maximum loads for unit load devices assume all equipment is installed and operable. When equipment is missing or inoperable, allowable loading may be reduced. Certain instances of missing or inoperable equipment reduce the allowable loading to zero.

caution.para: CARE MUST BE EXERCISED DURING LOADING AND UNLOADING OF UNIT LOAD DEVICES WHEN EQUIPMENT IS MISSING/INOPERATIVE TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO AIRCRAFT STRUCTURE. IT IS ADVISABLE THAT MALFUNCTIONING EQUIPMENT BE REPAIRED OR REPLACED TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO OPERATIVE EQUIPMENT.

numlitem.para: The following equipment malfunctions do not constitute a load limit restriction:
Jammed or missing sill rollers.

Restraint systems fall into four categories: side restraints, side/vertical restraints, forward/aft restraints and forward/aft/vertical restraints. Each restraint direction is considered separately when missing/inoperative restraint equipment exists (i.e. forward, aft, side left, side right and vertical loading). When a missing or inoperative restraint condition exists, the allowable weight is determined by considering each restraint direction separately and using the most limiting resultant allowable weight.
A lock is considered to be fully effective at the corner of a ULD if the centerline of the lockhead (pawl) lines up with the tangent of the ULD corner radius.
The following guidelines must be followed to determine allowable loads in a pallet position when missing or inoperable restraints are identified.
Determine the number of restraints available in each direction for each affected pallet position.
The ULD must be restrained vertically along all four sides.
A missing/inoperative side guide rail will cause the allowable weight for the affected position to be zero.

Missing/inoperative restraints in the same direction cannot be adjacent (i.e. two adjacent side restraints or two adjacent vertical restraints may not be missing or inoperative). Also, two restraints adjacent to a common corner cannot be missing/inoperable. If this condition exists, the allowable weight of the associated pallet position is 0 lb. (0 kg) except as noted in the following bullet.

An empty ULD can be carried in any position provided at least one restraint is operative in each (forward, aft, left and right) direction. In addition, one vertical restraint on each edge (forward, aft, left and right) must be operative.
The illustrations below identify the locations of the stops/locks/guides and the associated pallet positions for size codes A, M & N double locks for the aft compartment.
The locations below show the positions for the delivery configuration.

note.para: CRAF SIDE RESTRAINT FITTINGS Commercial configuration – No restrictions. CRAF Configuration – refer to CRAF manual for loading limitations based on inoperative lock location(s).
CRAF location numbering is same position with "C" added (i.e. P1C).
Centerline Side/Vertical restraints are not required for A or M size ULD’s. Weight restrictions for missing or inoperable centerline restraints are only applicable for N size units.

item.title: EMERGENCY LOCATOR TRANSMITTER (ELT) – FIXED ELT's – SYSTEM DEACTIVATED

Repairs are made within 90 days.

numlitem.para: Remote Control Switch is located in the Flight Compartment, in the pilot's P5 overhead control panel.
Ensure remote control switch is guarded and placard installed on top of switch. If switch is inoperative or guard is missing placard next to switch and perform step 2 below.

Locate Emergency Locator Transmitter (ELT). The ELT is mounted in a tray that is attached to the fuselage which is located in the aft section of the airplane (approximately station 2090), slightly forward of the L5 door in the overhead of the cargo compartment.
Move the ARMED/OFF/ON toggle switch to the off position.

item.title: Engine Fire Detector Systems – Flight Deck Test System

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided an alternate procedure is established to assure system integrity.

placard.para: Placard near FIRE/OVHT TEST Switch on P5 pilot’s overhead panel: "TEST FEATURE INOP". Enter Item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.title: ENGINE FIRE DETECTOR SYSTEMS FLIGHT DECK TEST SYSTEM
maintenance.para: The following CMC ground test procedure may be used to assure system integrity:

numlitem.para: Close circuit breakers (AMM 26-11-00/501).
Set either of the following switches to ENABLE position:
S2089 Ground Test Enable Switch (P461).
S2090 Remote Test Enable Switch (RCDU) at STA 400 bulkhead in the left main equipment center located near upper left side of ladder.
Set the CDU to the CMC main menu.
Press LINE SELECT key for GROUND TEST.
When screen displays ATA name and chapter, select 26 FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM.
To initiate test, press LINE SELECT key for FIRE/OVHT TEST.
The TEST IN PROGRESS indication will be displayed for the duration of the test.
When the test is done, the CDU will display TEST PASSED or FIRE TEST FAIL.

note.para: The indication FIRE TEST FAIL may appear as a result of circuit breaker being open on related fire/overheat detection system.

numlitem.para: If the indication is TEST PASSED, the test is finished and system integrity is verified.
If the indication is FIRE TEST FAIL, verify that the following CMC messages do not appear on CDU:
If CMC fault messages appear, seek corrective action. Note that dispatch is allowed with one loop per engine inoperative.
Close ENABLE position switch opened in step 2 above.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ENG ___ OVHT LP ___

numlitem.para: Close circuit breakers (AMM 26-11-00/501).

S2089 Ground Test Enable Switch (P461).

To initiate test, press LINE SELECT key for FIRE/OVHT TEST.
The TEST IN PROGRESS indication will be displayed for the duration of the test.
When the test is done, the CDU will display TEST PASSED or FIRE TEST FAIL.

note.para: The indication FIRE TEST FAIL may appear as a result of circuit breaker being open on related fire/overheat detection system.

numlitem.para: If the indication is TEST PASSED, the test is finished and system integrity is verified.
If the indication is FIRE TEST FAIL, verify that the following CMC messages do not appear on CDU:
If CMC fault messages appear, seek corrective action. Note that dispatch is allowed with one loop per engine inoperative.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided flight does not exceed three flight days before repairs are made.

note.para: Crew must be vigilant with regard to Crew Coordination in the execution of Immediate Action Items to verify the related Fuel Control Switch is placed to Cutoff position.

item.title: Main Deck Cargo Smoke Detector System – Flight Deck Test System

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided smoke detector system integrity is verified before each departure.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "MAIN CARGO DECK SMOKE DET SYS INOP". Enter Item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

note.para: The repetitive inspection required when this item is inoperative must be documented in the Aircraft Logbook at the prescribed intervals. (Refer to GMM, Chapter 3, Section 6.)

numlitem.para: Verify integrity of main deck cargo smoke detection system as follows:
Close circuit breakers (MM 26-14-00/501).
Select either one of the following switches to the ENABLE position:
S2089 Ground Test Enable Switch (P461).
S2090 Ground Test Enable Switch (RCDU) at STA 400 bulkhead in the left main equipment center located near upper left side of ladder.
Set CDU to the CMC main menu and press LINE SELECT key for GROUND TEST.
When screen displays ATA name and chapter, select 26 FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM.
Press LINE SELECT key to initiate FIRE/OVHT TEST. TEST IN PROGRESS will display for the duration of the test. Upon completion of the test, TEST PASSED or FIRE TEST FAIL will be displayed on the CDU.
If TEST PASSED is displayed, system integrity is verified.
If FIRE TEST FAIL is displayed:

note.para: FIRE TEST FAIL may appear because of a fault in a different fire/overheat detection system.

numlitem.para: Verify the following EICAS/CMC fault messages do not appear on the CDU:

entry.para: CARGO FIRE SIGNAL> MM-A CARD FAIL
CARGO FIRE SIGNAL> MM-B CARD FAIL

numlitem.para: If the above EICAS/CMC fault messages appear, seek corrective action: dispatch is not allowed.
Check for the following EICAS status messages:

para.emphasis: Freighter aircraft with Draw-Through Smoke Detection System:

numlitem.para: For each of the above EICAS status messages displayed, dispatch is allowed provided the associated cargo zone remains empty and:
* The associated zone(s) and the zone immediately forward of the associated zone(s) remain empty for above CMC fault message(s) listed and followed by one asterisk (*).
** The associated zone(s) and the two zones immediately forward of the associated zone(s) remain empty for above CMC fault message(s) listed and followed by two asterisks (**).
*** For detection zones 12 and/or 13, zones 10, 11, 12 and 13 remain empty.
Restore aircraft to its required configuration.

Main deck cargo compartment is empty or contains only empty cargo handling equipment.
