At takeoff, weights greater than 720,000 lbs., flaps up maneuver speed (VREF + 100) may exceed the landing gear retract speed (270 kts.). Therefore, ensure gear is retracted prior to selecting Flaps Up.
Downgrade Aircraft Category Dispatch Status to CAT 3a.
Compute V1 using the V1 correction, One or Two Brakes Deactivated or One or Two Anti-Skid Channels Inoperative worksheet in the AOM Chapter 5.1.
Apply takeoff performance runway weight corrections from the Takeoff Runway Limit Weight Reduction, Landing Gear Extended or Brake(s) Deactivated By Capping chart found in the AOM Chapter 5.1.
Apply restricted takeoff climb weights from the Takeoff Climb Limit Weight, Landing Gear Extended or Brake(s) Deactivated By Capping chart found in the AOM Chapter 5.1.
Apply landing weight performance for 1 or 2 brakes deactivated in the AA landing data.
If "Obstacle Clearance Altitude (OCA)" is present on the AA Data for the departure runway, contact Flight Control for alternate AA Data.
Operations on cluttered or icy runways prohibited.
Use cutback runway is prohibited.
Placard near Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel ____ Torque Limiter Control "INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.
The repetitive inspection required when this item is inoperative must be documented in the Aircraft Logbook at the prescribed intervals. (Refer to GMM, Chapter 3, Section 6.)

maintenance.para: Deferral of this item requires downgrading to the status indicated in the A/C STATUS DISPATCH column below.

para.revision: CAT 3a
If torque limiter control for one brake is inoperative, dispatch is allowed if:
Affected brake is deactivated.
The BRAKE LIMITER advisory and status level EICAS messages are not displayed following accomplishment of the Maintenance (M) procedure.
If torque limiter control for two brakes on the same truck is inoperative, dispatch is allowed if:
Both affected brakes are deactivated.
The BRAKE LIMITER advisory and status level EICAS messages are not displayed following accomplishment of the Maintenance (M) procedure.
BRAKE LIMITER advisory and status messages will again display if additional brake limiter faults occur affecting other wheel positions.
Only two brakes maximum can be deferred on aircraft at a time.

Inhibit of the BRAKE LIMITER EICAS messages associated with the brake limiter faults on the deactivated brakes requires that the aircraft have Brake System Control Unit P/N S283U002-5 (E9 Rack) or later version installed. Additional brake limiter faults which occur en route, that affect non-deactivated brake channels, will still be indicated by annunciation of the BRAKE LIMITER status and advisory level EICAS messages, as appropriate.
Deactivate the one or two affected brakes per MEL
Inhibit EICAS advisory and status level BRAKE LIMITER messages:

Rotate the two EICAS message inhibit knobs on the front face of the Brake System Control Unit (requires P/N S283U002-5 or later version installed) so that each knob points to a different wheel position number of the two deactivated brakes. The advisory and status level BRAKE LIMITER messages will no longer be annunciated for the selected wheel positions.

Once the inhibit knobs are set for the affected wheel positions, if additional brake limiter faults occur en route, affecting other wheel positions, EICAS will again display the status and/or advisory level EICAS messages as appropriate.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided alternate procedures are established and used.

numlitem.para: Establish communications with ground crew to notify them of Parking Brake Status.

placard.para: Placard on Nose Gear Status light: "NOSE GEAR STATUS LIGHT INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "NOSE PAD SNUBBER PAD(S) INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided AOM/AA Data Maximum Quick Turn-around Weight limitations are observed.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
BRAKE TEMP SYS

numlitem.para: Observe Maximum Quick Turnaround Weight limitations.
Apply a 10,000 lb weight penalty to the Quick Turnaround Limitation in AOM Chapter 5.2.

placard.para: Placard Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "BRAKE TEMP SYS INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Rudder Pedal Nose Wheel Steering System

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Other systems are not impaired, and
Landing approach minimums do not require automatic rollout guidance system.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
PEDAL STEERING

caution.para: WHEN USING THE TILLER IN PLACE OF RUDDER PEDAL NOSE WHEEL STEERING, PRUDENT HANDLING IS ADVISED, AS A SMALL MOVEMENT OF THE TILLER CAN CAUSE A LARGE CHANGE IN DIRECTION. PILOTS MUST USE CAUTION WHEN USING THE NOSE WHEEL STEERING TILLER AT SPEEDS ABOVE 20 KNOTS TO AVOID OVER-CONTROLLING THE NOSE WHEELS RESULTING IN POSSIBLE LOSS OF DIRECTIONAL CONTROL.

numlitem.para: TAKEOFF – The pilot with access to the nose wheel steering tiller will perform the takeoff. The pilot maintains directional control by steering first with the tiller and then transitioning to control solely with the rudder, as the rudder becomes fully effective. The transition from nose wheel steering to rudder control typically occurs between 60 to 80 knots and is normally completed by 80 knots. The tiller should be guarded until directional control is established with the rudder. The pilot flying should gradually release the pressure on the tiller while establishing the required amount of rudder control. The pilot not flying should hold a flight forward pressure on the control column and use the control wheel to maintain the wings level during the initial phase of the takeoff roll. At approximately 80 knots, when the pilot flying has transitioned from steering by means of the tiller to rudder control and has moved his hand from the tiller to the control wheel, the pilot not flying will release the control wheel.

LANDING – The pilot with access to the nose wheel steering tiller will perform the landing. The pilot flying should use the rudder and tiller as required during the landing roll and should be prepared to steer the aircraft, using the tiller, once the rudder has become ineffective (approximately 80 knots). The pilot not flying should assist by maintaining the wings level during the initial phase of the landing roll and holding a light forward pressure on the control column.
Downgrade Aircraft Category Dispatch Status to CAT 1.

placard.para: Placard Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "RUDDER PEDAL NOSE WHEEL STRG SYS INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.para: Deferral of this item requires downgrading to the status indicated in the A/C STATUS DISPATCH column below.

numlitem.para: Ensure that operation of rudder pedals is not impaired.
Ensure that the tiller steering is operative.
If it is necessary to deactivate the rudder pedal nose wheel steering system:
Remove the second center ceiling panel aft in the LH Forward Passenger Cabin (Zone A) to gain access to the rudder pedal steering interconnect mechanism (AMM 32-51-07/401).
Check that the following circuit breakers (P7 panel) are closed:
Prepare safety-sensitive systems for air mode simulation (AMM 32-09-02/201).

note.para: Putting the aircraft in air mode simulation will cause the engine probe heaters to turn on with the possibility of overheating and damaging the probes. It may be desirable to open circuit breakers for all four engine probe heaters during this maintenance procedure.

numlitem.para: Place proximity switch slugs (P/N A27092-61) at nose gear squat switch sensors.

note.para: In lieu of using a proximity switch slug, the Nose Landing Gear Torsion links Apex Pin may be disconnected and the torsion links carefully lowered. The upper link in the lowered position will provide proximity for the Squat Switch Sensors. To avoid potential for sensor damage, support the Upper Torsion Link until it is carefully lowered into position.

numlitem.para: Check that the rudder pedal interconnect mechanism moves to the disconnected position (i.e., that full travel of the rudder pedal does not move the interconnect mechanism quadrant).
Pull and collar the following circuit breakers on the P7 panel:.
Remove and stow the electrical connector from the nose gear steering interconnect actuators.
Remove installed proximity switch slug (or re-connect the Nose Landing Gear Torsion Links Apex Pin if disconnected).
Check that the nose gear steering system is operative using the tiller.
Check that the rudder is operative.
Install main deck ceiling panel.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Body gear steering actuators are verified locked, and
Body gear steering is deactivated.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
BODY GR STRG SYS
> BODY GEAR STRG
On takeoff, assure all 4 engines are spooled evenly at 70% N1, prior to engaging TOGA.

numlitem.para: With the body gear steering deactivated or inoperative, turning capability will be reduced. See the illustration in the AOM chapter 3 for the depiction of the approximate minimum turning radius using differential thrust in addition to nose wheel steering. As with all turns, the cockpit must travel outside the centerline of the turn to align the main path. The tip of the winglet describes the largest arc while turning and determines the minimum obstruction clearance path. All other portions of the aircraft structure are within this arc. It should be noted from the turning radius illustration that the wingtips are moved outboard about 11 feet, and travel 59 feet in front of the cockpit.

caution.para: DO NOT ATTEMPT TO MAKE A TURN AWAY FROM AN OBSTACLE WITHIN 11 FEET OF THE WINGTIP OR WITHIN 59 FEET OF THE COCKPIT.

numlitem.para: Avoid sharp turns if possible, due to excessive tire scrubbing.

caution.para: AVOID USE OF EXCESSIVE THRUST IN RAMP AREA DUE TO POSSIBLE DAMAGE OR INJURY FROM JET WAKE.

numlitem.para: Use modified GEAR LEVER WILL NOT MOVE UP Non-Normal Procedure for Body Gear Steering deactivated in the AOM Chapter 2.1 and QRH.
Minimum 170 feet of pavement required for 180 degree turn.

placard.para: Placard Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "BODY GEAR STRG SYS INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Verify body Gear Steering actuators are locked.

Perform the body gear steering actuator lock switch BITE test [AMM 32-53-16 procedure 3.F.15(a) through (i)]. Bit status of "1" indicates actuators are locked. Bit status of "0" indicates actuators may be unlocked or indication system may be inoperative (refer to DMP 32-53-2).
If any bit status indicates "0", verify actuator integrity as follows:
Depressurize hydraulic system No. 1.
Tow aircraft (using normal towing procedures) as follows, observing that no body gear steering actuator extension or separation occurs:
Nose wheel left 45 degrees, move 50 feet, stop.
Nose wheel right 45 degrees, move 50 feet, stop.
Repressurize hydraulic system No. 1.
Deactivate Body Gear Steering using Procedure A and if necessary, Procedure B (actuator leak) and/or Procedure C (control module leak or pressure switch fault).
PROCEDURE A
Remove nose gear torsion link apex pin and secure upper torsion link so that it clears structure when turning.
Open and collar the P7 panel BODY GR STRG ARM AC and BODY GR STRG ARM DC circuit breakers.
Using tiller, steer left and right at least 25 degrees. Verify that no body gear steering actuator extension occurs.
Reconnect nose gear torsion links.
PROCEDURE B - Use when steering actuator(s) leaks excessively.
Deactivate body gear steering using PROCEDURE A, then disconnect the left and/or right steering hydraulic system as follows:
Disconnect the OUTBD and INBD CYL EXT (extend) hoses and one RET (retract) hose from the associated body gear trunnion swivel fittings. Cap the trunnion swivel fittings.
Loosen the B nuts on EXT and RET hoses on the associated steering actuators. Drain the fluid from the hoses and re-tighten the B nuts.
Cap and stow the disconnected hoses so they clear the gear retraction swing.

Rotate the top disconnected swivel INBD EXT on the right body gear, and/or the OUTBD EXT on the left body gear, toward the nose of the aircraft to a horizontal position and secure there with lockwire. This prevents possible interferences with closing of slaved gear door.
Pressure check system.
PROCEDURE C - Use when the hydraulic control module(s) leak excessively or when a pressure switch indicates a fault.
Deactivate body gear steering using PROCEDURE A, then disconnect the leaky hydraulic control module(s) as follows (disconnect both modules for a pressure switch fault):
Depressurize hydraulic system No. 1.

Remove the pressure supply lines (P1) to the control module(s) (from the landing gear down LGD1 lines). Remove the return lines (R1) that connect to the top of the control module(s). Cap disconnected ports on tee line fittings. Stow tubes aboard aircraft.
Disconnect EXT and RET hoses at the associated steering actuators and drain lines. Reconnect hoses.
Cap open ports on the control module(s).
Pressure check system.
Restore hydraulic system No. 1 pressure.

note.para: The EICAS advisory message >BODY GEAR STRG may remain displayed due to a pressure switch fault.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Body gear steering actuators are verified locked,
Body gear steering is deactivated, and
Body gear steering actuator integrity is verified before each departure.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
BODY GR STRG SYS
> BODY GEAR STRG
On takeoff, assure all 4 engines are spooled evenly at 70% N1, prior to engaging TOGA.

numlitem.para: With the body gear steering deactivated or inoperative, turning capability will be reduced. See the illustration in the AOM chapter 3, for the depiction of the approximate minimum turning radius using differential thrust in addition to nose wheel steering. As with all turns, the cockpit must travel outside the centerline of the turn to align the main path. The tip of the winglet describes the largest arc while turning and determines the minimum obstruction clearance path. All other portions of the aircraft structure are within this arc. It should be noted from the turning radius illustration that the wingtips are moved outboard about 11 feet, and travel 59 feet in front of the cockpit.

caution.para: DO NOT ATTEMPT TO MAKE A TURN AWAY FROM AN OBSTACLE WITHIN 11 FEET OF THE WINGTIP OR WITHIN 59 FEET OF THE COCKPIT.

numlitem.para: Avoid sharp turns if possible, due to excessive tire scrubbing.

caution.para: AVOID USE OF EXCESSIVE THRUST IN RAMP AREA DUE TO POSSIBLE DAMAGE OR INJURY FROM JET WAKE.

numlitem.para: Use modified GEAR LEVER WILL NOT MOVE UP Non-Normal Procedure for Body Gear Steering deactivated in the AOM Chapter 2.1 and QRH.
Minimum 170 feet of pavement required for 180 degree turn.

placard.para: Placard Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "BODY GEAR STRG IND SYS INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

note.para: The repetitive inspection required when this item is inoperative must be documented in the Aircraft Logbook at the prescribed intervals. (Refer to GMM, Chapter 3, Section 6.)

The indication system is designed to display the EICAS advisory message >BODY GEAR STRG and status message BODY GR STRG SYS if the system is operating when not commanded. This requires that both body gear steering actuator lock switches (primary and alternate) indicate a body gear steering actuator is unlocked when the system is not armed. A single lock switch failure is not annunciated on EICAS, and does not constitute an inoperative indication system.

numlitem.para: Verify that the body gear steering actuators are locked using DMP 32-53-1 procedure 1.
Deactivate the body gear steering system using the appropriate procedure(s) from DMP 32-53-1.
Disconnect, cap and stow the electrical connector on the affected body gear steering actuator(s).
Before each departure, verify actuator integrity using DMP 32-53-1 procedure 1.B.1. through 1.B.3.

item.title: Body and Wing Landing Gear Uplock Position Sensors

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided the associated Primary and Alternate Landing Gear Door Warning Sensors are verified to be operative.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
GEAR DISAGREE
GEAR MONITOR

numlitem.para: When retracting the landing gear, to ensure the associated landing gear has operated properly, verify that the EICAS advisory level message GEAR DOOR does not display.

note.para: If advisory level message GEAR DOOR is displayed, accomplish GEAR DOOR Non-Normal procedure.
If Caution level message GEAR DISAGREE is displayed, accomplish GEAR DISAGREE Non-Normal procedure.

placard.para: Placard Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "B & W GR UPLK POS SENSOR INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

note.para: Dispatch is permitted if the cause of the Indication System failure is due to either Main Gear Uplock position sensors (Item 32-61-1-1), Landing gear Door warning sensors (Item 32-61-2) or Wing Gear Downlock position sensors (Item 32-61-3). Dispatch with faulty Nose Gear Up, Locked, Compressed sensors, Main Gear Tilt sensors or Body Gear Downlock sensors is not permitted, as this will affect essential systems including the Air/Ground System.

maintenance.para: Verify that the primary and alternate gear door warning sensors have not failed on the associated gear door by checking for the following CMC messages:

entry.para: X GEAR DOOR PRIMARY PROX SWITCH SENSOR FAIL (PSEU)
X GEAR DOOR ALTERNATE PROX SWITCH SENSOR FAIL (PSEU)
X GEAR DOOR PRIMARY PROX SWITCH TARGET FAIL (PSEU)
X GEAR DOOR ALTERNATE PROX SWITCH TARGET FAIL (PSEU)
X GEAR DOOR PRIMARY PROX SWITCH SENSOR/ WIRE FAIL (PSEU)
X GEAR DOOR ALTERNATE PROX SWITCH SENSOR/WIRE FAIL (PSEU)

item.chgdesc: Adds Note in Limitations.
item.title: Body and Wing Landing Gear Uplock Position Sensors – Gear Down

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Associated landing gear and its symmetric pair are secured in the down and locked position, and
Dispatch is in accordance with appropriate AOM/AA Data Gear Down appendix Chapter 5.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
GEAR DISAGREE
GEAR MONITOR

numlitem.para: Operate in accordance with landing gear extended performance.
If all landing gear are not to be left extended, use of the following procedure will keep all wheel well doors closed:
Before retraction of operable landing gear, depressurize the hydraulic system associated with the inoperative landing gear.

note.para: Note if Hydraulic system 1 is depressurized, gear retract braking is unavailable. Wait two minutes after takeoff before retracting landing gear to permit wheels to spin down prior to retraction.

numlitem.para: After gear retraction, position gear lever OFF.
Repressurize the hydraulic system associated with the inoperative landing gear.
Maximum operating speed is 270 KIAS/ 0.73 M.
Maximum takeoff weight is limited to 720,000 lbs.
RVSM operations prohibited.
Extended overwater operation prohibited.

para.revision: Extended Overwater operations is a horizontal distance of more than 50 NM from the nearest shoreline.

numlitem.para: If operations are conducted in known or forecasted icing conditions during any part of the flight and if the destination airport has a forecast landing temperature below 8°F, reduce the landing climb limit weight by 78,150 lbs.

placard.para: Placard Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "B & W GR UPLK POS SENSORS INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.title: BODY AND WING LANDING GEAR UPLOCK POSITION SENSORS

para.emphasis: Two or more Uplock Position Sensors Inoperative:

note.para: Dispatch is permitted if the cause of the Indication System failure is due to either Main Gear Uplock position sensors (Item 32-61-1-1), Landing gear Door warning sensors (Item 32-61-2) or Wing Gear Downlock position sensors (Item 32-61-3). Dispatch with faulty Nose Gear Up, Locked, Compressed sensors, Main Gear Tilt sensors or Body Gear Downlock sensors is not permitted, as this will affect essential systems including the Air/Ground System.

maintenance.para: If both uplock sensors (primary or alternate) on any main gear are failed, the affected landing gear and its symmetric landing gear pair must be secured in the down and locked position.

note.para: With both sensors on any main gear failed, the EICAS caution message GEAR DISAGREE may be displayed.

numlitem.para: Configure the landing gear (symmetric wing and/or body gear pairs) for gear down dispatch (AMM 32-00-00/201).
If all landing gear are to be left extended, pull and collar the landing gear lever lock circuit breaker on the P6 panel.
Configure the Mach/Airspeed Warning system as required by the AFM appendix.
Access the Gear Down Dispatch Switch in the main electronic equipment center.
Remove the safety wire from the switch guard.
Lift switch guard and place switch in the Gear Down Dispatch position.
Close switch guard and install safety wire.

remarks.para: One per door may be inoperative provided the associated operative sensor is verified to function correctly.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
GEAR MONITOR

numlitem.para: After dispatch, if advisory message GEAR DOOR is displayed, accomplish the Non-Normal procedure GEAR DOOR.

placard.para: Placard Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "DOOR INDICATION ON GEAR SYNOPTIC PAGE INOP." Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.para: Verify that at least one landing gear door warning sensor (primary or alternate) per gear is functioning correctly as follows:

numlitem.para: Isolate the landing gear door warning sensor fault(s) to the LRU level (AMM 32-09-03/501).
Verify that the primary and alternate gear door warning sensors have not both failed on any gear door, per the following CMC messages:

entry.para: X GEAR DOOR PRIMARY PROX SWITCH SENSOR FAIL (PSEU)
X GEAR DOOR ALTERNATE PROX SWITCH SENSOR FAIL (PSEU)
X GEAR DOOR PRIMARY PROX SWITCH TARGET FAIL (PSEU)
X GEAR DOOR ALTERNATE PROX SWITCH TARGET FAIL (PSEU)
X GEAR DOOR PRIMARY PROX SWITCH SENSOR/ WIRE FAIL (PSEU)
X GEAR DOOR ALTERNATE PROX SWITCH SENSOR/WIRE FAIL (PSEU)

item.chgdesc: Adds Note in Limitations.
item.title: Wing Landing Gear Downlock Position Sensors

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Both wing gear are secured in the down and locked position, and
Dispatch is in accordance with AOM/AA Data Gear Down appendix Chapter 5.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
GEAR MONITOR

numlitem.para: Operate in accordance with landing gear extended performance.
If all landing gear are not to be left extended, use of the following procedure will keep all wheel well doors closed:
Before retraction of operable landing gear, depressurize the hydraulic landing gear.
After gear retraction, position gear lever OFF.
Repressurize the hydraulic system associated with the inoperative landing gear.
Maximum operating speed is 270 KIAS/ 0.73 M.
Maximum takeoff weight is limited to 720,000 lbs.
RVSM operations prohibited.
Extended overwater operation prohibited.

para.revision: Extended Overwater operations is a horizontal distance of more than 50 NM from the nearest shoreline.

numlitem.para: If operations are conducted in known or forecasted icing conditions during any part of the flight and if the destination airport has a forecast landing temperature below 8°F, reduce the landing climb limit weight by 78,150 lbs.

placard.para: Placard Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "WING GR DNLOCK POS SENSORS INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.para: If one or both downlock sensors (primary or alternate) on any wing gear are failed, the affected landing gear and its symmetric landing gear pair must be secured in the down and locked position.

note.para: With both sensors on any main gear failed, the caution message GEAR DISAGREE may be displayed.

numlitem.para: Configure the landing gear (symmetric wing and/or body gear pairs) for gear down dispatch (AMM 32-00-00/201).
If all landing gear are to be left extended, pull and collar the landing gear lever lock circuit breaker on the P6 panel.
Configure the Mach/Airspeed Warning System as required by the Aircraft Flight Manual (AFM) appendix.
Access the Gear Down Dispatch Switch in the main electronic equipment center.
Remove the safety wire from the switch guard.
Lift switch guard and place switch in the Gear Down Dispatch position.
Close switch guard and install safety wire.

title.revision: Passenger Lighted Information Signs (No Smoking/Fasten Seat Belt/Return to Seat)

para.revision: May be inoperative provided:
Associated passenger seat, cabin attendant seat, lavatory or crew rest area bunk is not occupied from which a passenger lighted information sign is not readily legible, and
Associated seat, lavatory or bunk must be blocked and placarded – DO NOT OCCUPY.
These conditions are not intended to prohibit lavatory use or inspections by crewmembers.

placard.para: Placard seat, lav or bunk "Do Not Occupy". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: If required block off seat(s) from which a NO SMOKING/FASTEN SEAT BELT sign is not readily legible.

To determine if an individual sign is inoperative, an observer with normal vision should sit in the passenger seat(s) which is normally serviced by the sign, and determine if both a NO SMOKING and FASTEN SEAT BELT sign can be read from the seat(s).

note.para: In tests conducted at Boeing for the FAA, a sign was considered "readily legible" if enough of the sign could be seen to identify it. NO SMOK and FASTEN SEAT would be considered examples of signs that are readily legible.

numlitem.para: The flight crew will ensure that all persons in the upper deck are notified when seat belts should be fastened.

Upper deck occupancy is limited to those flight crewmembers essential to the flight (including official observer in forward observer seat) during takeoff or landing.
Ensure all occupants are briefed prior to takeoff and landing regarding which exits are available for emergency evacuation.
Only flight crewmembers (including official observer) occupy the upper deck.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Associated instruments operate from isolated sources, and
Inoperative switches are not moved in flight.
Inoperative switch(es) must not be moved once maintenance procedure as been completed.

placard.para: Install Placards near affected switch(es): "INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: To dispatch with instrument Source Select Switch(es) inoperative:
Position Captain's or First Officer's unaffected Source select Switch(es) so that both pilot's instruments are operating from different sources.
Verify that instruments associated with inoperative switch(es) operate from isolated sources by ensuring that the following advisory messages are not displayed.
>SOURCE SEL ADC
>SOURCE SEL EIU
>SOURCE SEL F/D
>SOURCE SEL IRS
>SOURCE SEL NAV

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided source is verified.

numlitem.para: Verify source for inoperative EIU Auto-Select feature:
Select L on Captain's EIU source selector and R or C on First Officer's selector.
Verify that advisory message >SOURCE SEL EIU is not displayed.

remarks.para: May be inoperative.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "SAT IND INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided left and right ADC's are operative.

placard.para: Placard below Captain's PFD on P-1-1 panel: "P/S XFR VLV INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Select Center ADC on the First Officer's Air Data Source Selector (P3).
If EICAS status message P/S XFR VLV is displayed, placard the First Officer's Air Data Source Selector Center position – INOP.
Subsequently, select Right ADC on the First Officer's Air Data Source Selector (P3 panel).
If EICAS status message P/S XFR VLV is displayed, placard the Captain's Air Data Source Selector Center position – INOP.
If EICAS status message P/S XFR VLV was displayed in both of the preceding steps, the Center ADC must be considered inoperative using MEL item 34-12-1.

note.para: EICAS status message P/S XFR VLV may remain displayed provided the Captain's and First Officer's Air Data Source Selectors are not selected to an inoperative position.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided at least the left, and one other ADC is operative.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ADC ____

numlitem.para: Flight crew should verify the left ADC and either the right or center ADC is operative.

placard.para: Placard below Captain's PFD on P-1-1 panel: "C or R ADC INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.para: Deferral of this item requires downgrading to the status indicated in the A/C STATUS DISPATCH column below.
If Status Message ADC RIGHT is annunciated, the following procedure for selecting the Center ADC is recommended:

numlitem.para: Select Center ADC on F/O P3 panel.

note.para: Center ADC must be selected prior to proceeding to step 2.

numlitem.para: Determine if Status Message AOA RIGHT is displayed.
If AOA RIGHT is not displayed, dispatch is allowed.
If AOA RIGHT is displayed, locate circuit breaker ADC R PWR on P7 panel.
If circuit breaker ADC R PWR is closed, dispatch is not allowed.
If circuit breaker ADC R PWR is open, close it one time ONLY and wait 30 seconds:
If circuit breaker ADC R PWR re-opens, dispatch is not allowed.
If circuit breaker ADC R PWR remains closed, and AOA RIGHT is not displayed, dispatch is allowed.

item.chgdesc: Renumbers item and revises proviso per MMEL. Adds Limitation.

title.revision: Altitude Alerting System

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

para.revision: Autopilot with altitude hold, and altitude capture are operative,

numlitem.para: En route operations do not require its use,

para.revision: Aircraft does not depart from a designated airport where repair or replacement can be made, and
Repairs are made within three flight days.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
ALT ALERT SYS

caution.para: USUAL ALERTS FOR ALTITUDE DEVIATIONS WILL NOT OCCUR.

numlitem.para: Any one of the following autopilot modes will provide acceptable altitude hold capability:
Altitude Hold (ALT HOLD)
Vertical Speed (V/S) with 000 selected
Vertical Navigation (VNAV) with FMC flight plan, or
VNAV with FMC flight plan combined with altitude intervention
Use the autopilot and altitude hold capability for all operations for which it is appropriate.
Cross-check the altitude displays between the Captain’s and First Officer’s PFD upon reaching and departing an assigned altitude.
Pilot Monitoring (PM) should call out approaching and departing assigned altitudes.
Periodically cross-check altitude when maintaining altitude.
Operations in RVSM airspace is prohibited.
Modify ATC flight plan suffix to the appropriate code.

para.revision: Designated Altitude Alerting System repair Airports are SDF, PHL and Ont.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on PFD P-1-1 panel: "ALT ALERTING SYS INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

IRS CENTER
Manual selection of the operable IRS is required to ensure the interfacing systems (i.e., in addition to the displays) are supplied with data from the operable IRU.

numlitem.para: Downgrade Aircraft Category Dispatch Status to CAT 2.
North Polar Routes prohibited.

maintenance.para: Deferral of this item requires downgrading to the status indicated in the A/C STATUS DISPATCH column below.

numlitem.para: Approach minimums do not require its use, and
Standby power to the Captain’s ND is installed and available.

note.para: All UPS aircraft have standby power to the captain’s ND.
North Polar Route Restrictions.

IRS RIGHT
Manual selection of the operable IRS is required to ensure the interfacing systems (i.e., in addition to the displays) are supplied with data from the operable IRU.

numlitem.para: Downgrade Aircraft Category Dispatch Status to CAT 2.
North Polar Routes prohibited.

FANS Operations prohibited.
RNP -4 Operations prohibited.

numlitem.para: If the left ILS is inoperative, GPWS mode 5 (GS Deviation) is considered inoperative.
The flight crew should observe the following:
Flight crew should be vigilant monitoring aircraft altitude and flight path.
Flight crew should use all systems available to include the use of autopilot, auto land, ILS, FMCS to include RNAV/GPS.
Modify Approach Briefing appropriate for the existing meteorological conditions.
Downgrade Aircraft Category Dispatch Status to CAT 3a.

item.title: RADIO ALTIMETERS (RA) – SINGLE SOURCE DATALINK TO GPWS – LEFT RA

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Dispatch deviation for GPWS inoperative is observed,
Approach minimums or operating procedures do not require its use,
Right RA is operative,
Boeing Service Bulletin 747-31-2410 or production equivalent is incorporated, and
Repairs are made within two flight days.

note.para: Service Bulletin 747-31-2410 has been incorporated on all UPS aircraft.
The following EICAS messages may be displayed:
RADIO ALT___
NO LAND 3
If EICAS message GND PROX SYS is displayed, dispatch must be in accordance with MEL 34-46-1, Ground Proximity Warning System, Inoperative.

numlitem.para: Visual approaches are not authorized with GPWS inoperative. Instrument approach procedures must be used.
Downgrade Aircraft Dispatch Status to CAT 3a.

placard.para: Placard below Captain's PFD on P-1-1 panel “LEFT RADIO ALT INOP”. Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

note.para: Radio Altimeters (RAs) are interchangeable, and operative left RA is preferred.
For proper operation of the Autopilot Flight Director System (AFDS) takeoff and approach modes, an operative RA and FCC on the same side (L/R) is required.

maintenance.para: If necessary, the radio altimeters may be interchaged as follows:

numlitem.para: Open the P7 panel RAD ALTM L, RAD ALTM C and RAD ALTM R circuit breakers.
Interchange the Radio Altimeters (located in the center equipment center - E9 Rack).
Close the circuit breakers opened above.

note.para: The following EICAS messages may be displayed:
RADIO ALT___
NO LAND 3

note.para: Radio Altimeters (RAs) are interchangeable, and operative left RA is preferred.

item.title: Radio Altimeters (RA) – Multi-Source Datalink to GPWS Two Inoperative

remarks.para: Two may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: GPWS is supplied with Radio altitude data, and
Approach minimums or operating procedures do not require their use.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
RADIO ALT ___
NO LAND 3
If more than one RA is inoperative autoland is not authorized and NO AUTOLAND will be displayed.

numlitem.para: Observe LIMITATIONS/PERFORMANCE PENALTIES.
Downgrade Aircraft Category Dispatch Status to CAT 1.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "MULTI-SOURCE DATALINK INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Verify that status message GND PROX SYS is not displayed. If it is, there is a fault in the GPWS itself and dispatch might not be allowed. GPWS Modes 1 thru 4 and the TEST mode must be operative and are not deferrable. Modes 5 thru 7 may be deferrable under MEL's 34-46-1-X-X.

maintenance.para: Deferral of this item requires downgrading to the status indicated in the A/C STATUS DISPATCH column below.

note.para: It is recommended that the remaining RA(s) have an associated operative FCC (i.e., Left RA and Left FCC both operative). This will insure proper operation of the Autopilot Flight Director System (AFDS) takeoff and approach modes.

item.title: Radio Altimeters (RA) – Multi-Source Datalink to GPWS One Inoperative

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: GPWS is supplied with Radio altitude data, and
Approach minimums or operating procedures do not require their use.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
RADIO ALT ___
NO LAND 3

numlitem.para: Observe LIMITATIONS/PERFORMANCE PENALTIES.
Downgrade Aircraft Category Dispatch Status to CAT 2.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "MULTI-SOURCE DATALINK INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Verify that status message GND PROX SYS is not displayed. If it is, there is a fault in the GPWS itself and dispatch might not be allowed. GPWS Modes 1 thru 4 and the TEST mode must be operative and are not deferrable. Modes 5 thru 7 may be deferrable under MEL's 34-46-1-X-X.

maintenance.para: Deferral of this item requires downgrading to the status indicated in the A/C STATUS DISPATCH column below.

note.para: It is recommended that the remaining RA(s) have an associated operative FCC (i.e., Left RA and Left FCC both operative). This will insure proper operation of the Autopilot Flight Director System (AFDS) takeoff and approach modes.

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Weather radar is not required by FAR, and
Reactive windshear alert (GPWS Mode 7) is operative.

note.para: The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
WXR SYS

numlitem.para: May be inoperative for day VMC.

May be inoperative for IMC provided that no thunderstorms or other potentially hazardous weather conditions that can be detected with airborne weather radar are forecast or may reasonably be expected along the route of the flight.

note.para: In the case of daylight flights, the specification “IMC” does not necessarily mean that the entire flight must be conducted under VMC if the radar is inoperative, but only that the aircraft must remain in the clear throughout the area of thunderstorms or other hazardous weather, visually circumnavigating all such weather.

numlitem.para: Dispatch not authorized when thunderstorms or other potentially hazardous weather conditions can be detected with airborne weather radar may reasonably be expected along the route to be flown.

note.para: Dispatch allowed when the flight is planned to avoid any potential thunderstorms or hazardous weather.

placard.para: Placard near appropriate weather radar selector switch: "WEATHER RADAR INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

item.title: Weather Radar System – Both Inoperative – GPWS Mode 7 Inoperative

remarks.para: May be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Weather radar is not required by FAR, and
Alternate procedures are established and used.

note.para: Operator's alternate procedures should include reviewing windshear avoidance and windshear recovery procedures.
The following EICAS message(s) may be displayed:
WXR SYS
WINDSHEAR PRED
WINDSHEAR SYS

numlitem.para: May be inoperative for day VMC.

May be inoperative for IMC provided that no thunderstorms or other potentially hazardous weather conditions that can be detected with airborne weather radar are forecast or may reasonably be expected along the route of the flight.
Review/Brief WINDSHEAR, Avoidance, Precautions, Recognition and Recovery procedures, AOM Chapter 2.0.

note.para: In the case of daylight flights, the specification "IMC" does not necessarily mean that the entire flight must be conducted under VMC if the radar is inoperative, but only that the aircraft must remain in the clear throughout the area of thunderstorms or other hazardous weather, visually circumnavigating all such weather.

numlitem.para: No IMC or night dispatch where potentially hazardous weather conditions, which can be detected by airborne weather radar, may reasonably be expected to be encountered along the route.
Takeoffs and landings are not conducted in known or forecasted windshear conditions.

placard.para: Placard near appropriate weather radar selector switch: "WEATHER RADAR INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

remarks.para: One may be inoperative provided one weather radar system is operative.

placard.para: Placard near appropriate weather radar selector switch: "WEATHER RADAR INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

note.para: Operator’s alternate procedures should include reviewing windshear avoidance and windshear recovery procedures.

WINDSHEAR SYS

numlitem.para: Review/Brief WINDSHEAR, Avoidance, Precautions, Recognition and Recovery procedures, AOM Chapter 2.0.

placard.para: Placard near both weather radar selector switches: "WINDSHEAR PREDICTIVE MODE INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

TCAS SYSTEM

numlitem.para: Operate TCAS in transponder-only mode by selecting TCAS Mode Selector to XPNDR position.
Flight Control to ensure TCAS is not required by Foreign States along planned route.

placard.para: Placard below Captain’s PFD on P-1-1 panel: "TCAS INOP". Enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

numlitem.para: Deactivate the TCAS system by opening and collaring the P7 panel TCAS circuit breaker.

note.para: Pilot with the operative Advisory and Display System must act as Pilot Flying.
